We're scared of technology and progress. We don't want any of that. We don't want any of these highfalutin, new, modern devices like telecommunications. We want to put it back in the box where Santamaria says it deserves to be, where Santamaria wants it to be and where John Howard wants our society to be—rooted in the 1950s.'

Fancy the member for Warringah wanting to lecture the House about parliamentary behaviour. This is the member for Warringah who had the hide and the gall to describe the Australian Prime Minister (Mr Keating) as Jack the Ripper. This is the same member for Warringah who, when he was at the monastery, was known not as Jack the Ripper but as Tony the Stripper. If he wants to engage in those sorts of standards—jumping fences in and out of the monastery and bringing that low level of behaviour into parliamentary forums—he is going to get it back with spades.

This exposes the humbug and the cant of what the opposition have been saying in this debate. It also exposes the funny old position they have got themselves in. In 1993 at the last election, which was not so long ago, they put forward all the things they believed in. They worked for two or three years, and the member for Warringah was in the research team working on all the ideas that the Liberal Party and the National Party really believed in. What they came up with was called Fightback, but that is locked away now like a mad uncle in the attic.

The opposition never talks about Fightback, but Fightback reflects all the things they believe in—the individual employment contracts, the dismantling of Medicare, the 15 per cent GST and the cutting away of all the public sector programs that provide for an equalising and civilising society. They are fundamental political beliefs, and the things that were reflected in the Fightback manifesto are just an echo of Thatcherite philosophy—the idea that there is no such thing as society: there is government and there are individuals, but there is no partnership between the two; there is no partnership between government and individuals to form a thing called society.

Their sole role in politics is to push away public sector programs and to push more and more responsibility on to individuals. Of course, the wealthy and the privileged in our society can pick up those responsibilities and entrench their position. For the disadvantaged—the people they would call battlers—it is even harder because, without the civilising and equalising role and the great tolerance and liberation of the public sector, those so-called battlers have an even harder lot in their lives.

What happened after 1993 when they found out that the things that they believed in and the policies they supported in Fightback were basically unelectable and unsupported by the Australian people? In 1996 they are going to go to the electorate with things they do not believe in. What sort of empty shell of a party is this? In 1993 they went to the people with all the things they believed in and found out they were unelectable; now they are trying to put on the fraud and the hypocrisy of going to the election next year with all the things that they do not believe in.

This is exposing the two faces of John Howard. The member for Warringah and other speakers have said, `The Labor Party can't make up its mind. They seem to be campaigning against two John Howards.' There is a perfect reason why we are doing that. There are two John Howards. There is the private John Howard who believes in all the policies of Fightback, and there is the public John Howard who is trying to present himself to the people of Australia as a sensitive New-Age guy—as a reborn political leader; the sort of leader who eats quiche; the sort of leader who helps little old ladies across the road; the reborn, sensitive New-Age John Howard. It is a fraud and the Australian people will not have a bar of it.

The Australian people know the two faces of John Howard. They know the face of the private John Howard who supports Fightback to his bootstraps. They also know the public John Howard who is now trying to have a massive lend of the Australian people. The Australian people will determine at the next election that they like neither face of John Howard and they will reject both comprehensively at the ballot box.

This reflects something interesting about the coalition at this part of the political cycle. Those opposite know that they are going to the people with the things that they do not believe in. They are sort of half excited and half geed up by the fact that opinion polls show that they are a bit ahead. They are getting around with a hangdog look and saying, `We are really not going to the people and getting a mandate for the things that we believe in.' However, they are half excited about the prospect of a coalition government.

This is a party with an empty shell. This is a party that is totally poll driven and has no conviction, has no integrity and has no purpose for its existence. Without those things called conviction, ideology, policy and belief in politics and public life there can be no achievement. There can be no achievement without those key ingredients as a meaningful existence in public life.

The members of the Liberal Party and the National Party must sit around in the dining room and the party room wondering, `What has it all been for? What has it all been for in 13 years of opposition?' The opposition has spent most of the 1980s shaking out the ideology and the direction of the Liberal Party. It was Howard versus Peacock. It was Left versus Right. It was wet versus dry. It was a party ripping itself apart to refashion its core beliefs and its core ideology for the 1990s.

What does the coalition have going into the next election? What does the opposition have in its leadership? They have Andrew Peacock writ small. They have Andrew Peacock without a suntan. They have Andrew Peacock without Shirley MacLaine. They have Andrew Peacock without the Gucci toothbrush. They have Andrew Peacock without the serious look. All they have left is John Howard and the worried look.

They have gone through this massive process of ideological struggle in the 1980s of the wets versus the drys, Howard versus Peacock and Left versus Right to end up with a Peacock style of leadership—all image, no substance—led by John Howard. It is an absolute fraud. All the opposition is left with is the worried look, the constipated look, that sits permanently on the face of the Leader of the Opposition.

It is a sad old state for a party left without a heart, left without conviction and left without core political belief. Those opposite are not going to the people with the things they believe in and the things they showed to the Australian public in the Fightback manifesto. This is the same John Howard who said in his budget reply speech earlier this year:

SPEECH.PARA: I have dedicated my public life to the pursuit of substantive policy change, and I have led the debate.
It is a funny way to lead the debate by trying to hide your policies. It is a funny way to lead the debate and produce substantive policy change by campaigning on the things you do not believe in.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition is Australia's answer to Jim Hacker. His motto is, `I am their leader. I must follow them.' It is the same John Howard who adopted that motto when he was Treasurer between 1977 and 1983—the Treasurer who showed leadership by walking away from the internationalisation of the Australian economy. He is the same Treasurer who showed substantive policy change by walking away from tariff reduction, micro reform, industrial relations reform and integrating Australia into the Asia-Pacific region. This is the same John Howard who has the hide to come into this parliament on this debate and want to talk about economic performance.

The Leader of the Opposition produced some figures from the Business Council. I have a better source of figures—the Parliamentary Library. Those on the opposite side of the House wish to compare the performance of this government on economic management. Who would they take as their standard? Who would they take as their benchmark? Is it the Menzies government? Would that be a fair comparison with the performance of the Labor government from 1983 to the present?

In this parliament we hear the Menzies era described as the utopian age of economic growth, the utopian age of economic performance in Australia and the golden age of Liberal government. Members opposite would surely accept the proposition that it is a valid comparison to look at the economic performance of the Menzies government from 1949 to 1966 against the Hawke-Keating government's performance from 1983 to 1995.

What do the figures provided by the Parliamentary Library show? On the key performance measure of growth in GDP per capita per annum the performance of the Menzies government was two per cent and for the Hawke-Keating government it was 2.1 per cent. We are greater than Menzies; we are greater than the golden age on the key measure of economic performance—GDP per capita per annum. Another measure is employment. Under Menzies the annual growth was 2.1 per cent and under this government it was 2.1 per cent—just as good. If we take business investment as a proportion of GDP, under Menzies it was 10.7 per cent and under Hawke-Keating it was an average of 10.8 per cent. On inflation, Menzies was 4.6 per cent and under this government it was 5.4 per cent—trying to wind back from the Howard legacy.

When it comes to the key measure, the thing that the Liberal Party and the National Party would really pride themselves on in the 1990s is government outlays—growth in the public sector. We had an interesting reminder of this just last Sunday on that infamous Meet the Press program when the Leader of the Opposition said, `Oh, there is not as much fat in the system as there was 15 years ago.' It is almost as if he has forgotten who was in 15 years ago. Who was the Treasurer responsible for a fat budget 15 years ago? J.W. Howard!

How selective and how convenient that he can stand there on a national TV program and say, `There is not as much fat in the system as there was 15 years ago,' without saying who was responsible for the fat a decade and a half ago. It was him. This is the man with no history. He is the Ronald Biggs of Australian politics. He was not there 15 years ago at the scene of the crime; it was someone else.

On this key measure of comparison, let me return to the figures. We are looking at the Menzies period compared with that of Hawke and Keating. For Commonwealth outlays under Menzies we had 2.5 per cent growth per annum; under this government it is 1.5 per cent—a lean, effective, efficient Labor government. When it comes to Commonwealth taxation we always hear the opposition say that this is a high taxing government. Have a look at Menzies' performance. We see that annual growth in Commonwealth taxation receipts was two per cent and under this government it is 1.1 per cent.

We are better than the golden age. This is a new definition of economic utopia established by this government. This has occurred under this government. I have used a comparison that the Liberal Party and the National Party would say is the only fair comparison of postwar economic performance. So this is a good government.

It was once said of Jack Lang that he was greater than Lenin. When one looks at the economic data, is the opposition now going to confess that Paul Keating is greater than Menzies? What the opposition is basically saying in this debate, and what it will be putting forward at the next campaign, is that on the economic data this government is better than the Menzies government from 1949 to 1966. The opposition is saying, `We have no policies but we want to be in government.' The Labor government has done better than the golden age—the utopian age—of Menzies. Those opposite have no policies but they want to be on this side of the House.

That is such a sham; that is such a fraud to be putting to the Australian people. They have no policies but what have they got in personnel? They have got John Howard, the third choice—not of the Australian people in this term of parliament but of his peers. He was not good enough to beat John Hewson in their leadership ballot; not good enough to beat Alexander Downer, the second choice; but was relegated to the third choice—not the third choice of the Labor Party, not the third choice of the Australian people but the third choice of his peers in this session of parliament. He is the most overrated character that Australian politics has seen for a long while.

How long do you need to be in this place to know the fundamental tenets of pension policy? How long do you need to be here? He has been here 21 years and he does not know that this government has achieved pensions at the level of 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. Does he need another 21 years? Is it 42 years before he finds out the basis of policy for the old age pension?

Then there is Tim Fischer. One unnamed National Party member—possibly the member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran)—said last week, `With Tim, we don't know if it is a lack of intellectual capacity or intestinal fortitude or both.' We know the answer on this side: it is both. It is lack of intellectual capacity and intestinal fortitude. When it comes to the Leader of the National Party, he is not only dumb and dumber but also weak and weaker. He is the weakest figure in the history of Australian politics.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Do you claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—Please proceed.

—Today in Senate question time Senator Cook made false allegations regarding my motives when I sought to prevent CSIRO from allowing the erection of billboards on their green space along South Road at O'Halloran Hill in Adelaide. Senator Cook said, `It is interesting to ask the question: why does Mrs Gallus have an interest in ending this project? She told the CSIRO it was to give other companies a chance to bid for the contract to erect boardings.' What was said was not correct as my opposition was on environmental grounds only and I was opposed to the erection of billboards by any and all companies on the O'Halloran Hill site.
—Mr Speaker, I would like you to be aware that, whatever the reason, it is impossible to hear the member for Hindmarsh. Perhaps the volume could be turned up.
—Okay.
—I was opposed to the erection of billboards by any and all companies on the O'Halloran Hill site.
—Order! The honourable member is now debating the issue.

—No. Mr Speaker, I did raise the issue of the CSIRO's failure to obtain approvals from the Marion Council and its not following normal government tendering procedures. However, these actions were taken only to strengthen my case to prevent an act of environmental vandalism which Senator Cook should also criticise, instead of imputing untrue motives and defending the indefensible. I will continue to oppose the erection of any billboards by any and all companies on the CSIRO site at O'Halloran Hill.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Do you claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—Please proceed.

—In this morning's Canberra Times, in an article edited by Simon Grose, there is an attempt to link me in some way to the same measure of culpability that the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton) and the honourable member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence) have. I point out that in the matters to which that article refers I paid all my own legal fees, I stood down from cabinet and I was acquitted on all charges—in contrast to both those honourable members.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Do you claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins) took the chair at 10.00 a.m.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

PARA.TAB: Debated resumed from 29 November, on motion by Mr Price:
That the House take note of the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson), who chaired the foreign affairs subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee of Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I am pleased to see him in the chamber, although it would have helped if he had been here earlier. I am pleased that this motion gives us the opportunity to discuss matters relating to Thailand. As you mentioned yesterday in the discussion of the paper, I led a parliamentary delegation to Thailand in September of this year. You, Mr Deputy Speaker Scott, were a member of that delegation, and its deputy leader was the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur). The other members of the delegation were Senator Watson and the member for Richmond (Mr Newell).

PARA.TAB: This report, Australia's relations with Thailand, produced by the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, is a very useful document for those who wish to develop an understanding of matters relating to Thailand. As is mentioned in the foreword to the report, and by members who have already spoken on this subject, the report does not set out to lecture the Thai government. It is directed at a number of issues that are important to the relationship between Australia and Thailand. The report raises issues that are of great importance to us in our dealings with a number of countries throughout the world, particularly in the Asian region.

There is a very significant section on industrial relations matters. The committee has made a number of recommendations urging the Australian government to do all that is possible to encourage, persuade and assist the Thai government in ratifying a number of important ILO conventions.

As the report explains, the Thai government has not entered into any international labour agreements since 1967. As we have already had discussions about labour practices in a number of countries, I do not think that Australia should shy away from placing on record its strong beliefs on matters such as child labour or occupational health and safety.

Of course, all of these things have a cultural context but, as an economy and a nation such as Thailand develops, it is important that it understands that there is an international expectation about matters that should go with that development. I do not think that anybody is saying that these things can occur overnight. A number of these things have to be worked at and worked progressively.

I have a number of items I wish to raise because I think it is important that one gets one's impressions about a country on the record. We hoped to be able to report on our delegation before the end of this year. For a number of reasons, that will now not be possible but we hope to be able to report in the new year.

The parliamentary delegation's visit to Thailand was associated with our status as an observer delegation in the week following in Singapore at the IPO conference. It has been the tradition of IPO observer delegations from Australia to visit an ASEAN country which is a member of IPO, to get a better appreciation of it. As has been said in this debate, and as is said in the report, it would be a bit rich for Australian parliamentary committees and Australian parliamentarians to get up, wax lyrical and highlight problems about a country if, in fact, they had not made the attempt to visit countries to get an understanding about the issues and the cultural context in which those issues are tackled. The right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) quite rightly highlighted that in his contribution to this debate.

The report of the joint committee highlights a number of matters, and I will briefly mention a few of them. One, of course, is the importance of the Thai royal family, in the sense not only of their role as part of a constitutional monarchy, but also of the deep respect and reverence that the people of Thailand have for their royal family. The delegation was in Thailand during the period of mourning for Her Royal Highness the Princess Mother. As part of our duties during the time that we were in Bangkok, we went and paid our respects to the Princess Mother. One of the things that amazed the delegation, as you are well aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, was the number of people queuing to pay their respects. We were also informed of how many additional visitors had come from rural regions of Thailand to visit Bangkok with the express purpose of paying their respects. To see thousands of people queuing for several hours, dressed in black, some with a great deal of effort, was an indication of the high regard in which the royal family is held.

To this degree, I think that it is quite appropriate that one of the recommendations of the joint committee's report is that the government investigate how Australia might play its part and join in the celebrations next year of the golden jubilee of His Majesty the King of Thailand's succession to the throne. That anniversary will occur on 9 June 1996. In the context of what I observed as part of the delegation, I think that that is a quite an appropriate recommendation.

Another matter that is always raised with anybody visiting Bangkok is the problem of traffic. In our planning for the delegation, I thought that this was perhaps overstated. When we tried to find out why we had only one appointment in the morning and one in the afternoon—it seemed a pretty light workload and I did not wish to have the allegation made that we were in some way a slack delegation—we were told that, realistically, it was about all we could expect because we would spend the rest of the time stuck in traffic.

On most occasions we were fairly lucky as, with the assistance of the constabulary, we were able to wend our way through the traffic in a relatively efficient manner, sometimes in a fairly scary manner, because you drive up the wrong side of the road with horns blazing and people waving gloved palms that somehow magically stop you. Bangkok traffic is symbolic of a great problem that Thailand has to tackle.

We met with Dr Narongchai, who is a respected financier and economist who heads up the Thai-Australia Business Council. He was educated in Western Australia and his two children are being educated in Victoria, one at Geelong Grammar and one at RMIT. Dr Narongchai has a house in Melbourne and a great affection for Australia—something that we struck throughout our visit.

When we asked him about Bangkok traffic he was quite blunt in saying to the delegation that no English words were adequate to describe it. I think that that summed up the frustration. He went on to say that the only certainty he had was that it would get worse. It is something that Australian businesses that have some expertise in these sorts of things can assist with. Efforts are being made to put public transport systems in place but, given the way that the city of Bangkok has developed, that is going to be a very difficult thing.

The Deputy Prime Minister of Thailand made a very brave prediction that the traffic problems in Bangkok would be solved within six months. Some of the English-Thai papers are running what they call `Mr Thaksin's clock', because they are monitoring the progress, time for which is running out, over the six-month period. Given what we observed, I do not like his chances of being successful. But Thais have to tackle the problem to increase their standing and ability to attract international business, because it is currently seen as an impediment.

The right honourable member for New England mentioned to me after his contribution that he would have liked to have made some remarks about the recent floods in Thailand. I think that we all express our sympathy to those that were involved. One of the problems for Bangkok is that it is built alongside a tidal river and is always under a degree of threat. When we were in Thailand, there was flooding in the mid-region provinces, which meant that we had a problem of land transport at one stage in our visit. Given the nature of the river systems of Thailand and the peninsula, it is another problem that will always be with Thailand.

The flooding problem is illustrative of the environmental problems that have to be confronted. The government has tried to tackle the problem of forests, which has led to a tightening up on the use of the forests but has in turn brought tension into the relationship across the Burmese border, for instance, where some of the logging companies have moved in. I know that it is quite appropriate that two reports, one on Thailand and the other on human rights in Myanmar, should be being debated at the same time because the Thai government does have to tackle its relationship with Burma.

In the remaining few minutes, I would like to mention our visit to the displaced persons camp on the Burmese border, a camp that is run under the auspices of the BBC—the Burmese Border Consortium—which is a collection of non-government agencies that work with refugees. These displaced people do not have refugee status, only because the Thai government has not entered into the relevant international agreement. Again, the committee's report is quite correct in urging that moves be made to give assistance to the Thais to come to grips with their ability to sign that agreement.

The camp we visited was a very efficiently run camp, but the sad thing was that it has been in existence for 11 years. We were entertained by form 5 students who had had all their education in the camp. Because they had attained year 11 level, that was as far as their education was going to go. There was no other form of education available to them. This is a problem that needs to be addressed, because these people are not seeking resettlement in Thailand or anywhere else. They fervently want the ability to return to Burma, and to return to a Burma that would allow them to exist in the way they had done previously and to retain their ethnic identity. The people we visited were the Karen, and all they want is the ability to return to Burma and to get on with their lives.

There is a difficulty in the way the relationship between Thailand and Burma has developed, in that the Thais see an economic advantage. Perhaps they are skirting some of the issues that they really need to talk through to ensure that people such as those we were able to visit in the camps are able to return to Burma and do what they want to do. They want to get on with life in their part of Myanmar and retain their identity. I congratulate all those associated with this report. It is a very useful document.

That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, I was not a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade subcommittee that has produced the report on human rights and progress towards democracy in Burma; but, from my reading of it, it is fair to say that it certainly covers the spectrum of issues. I want to record my appreciation of the work that has gone into this particular report, which covers the very clear central role of ethnic minority issues and the fact that, since the assassination of Aung San in 1948, the promise of Burma's being able to develop a system of confederations amongst the various Chin, Shan and Karen and Karenni people has disappeared.

PARA.TAB: The difficulties of Burma are very much associated with the belief that the only way that Burma could survive as a nation was through a very crucial role for the armed forces. This is one of the excuses that the Burmese military establishment has utilised in the decades since. It says that it is threatened by insurrection, by guerilla forces and, at one stage, by the Communist Party of Burma and the various aligned minority groups. The assassination of Aung San, the father of the current internationally acclaimed human rights leader, was a crucial factor in the spiral that has occurred since 1948, and the report very much deals with that matter.

The comment on page (xiii) of the report—that reality `requires the perpetrators of abuses to be brought to justice, the establishment of an independent judiciary and a free press, a recognition of the rights of a democratic opposition and the subordination of the army to an elected civilian government'—really does summarise what should be sought here. Since the 1988 crackdown, the arrest and imprisonment of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the assumption of power by the State Law and Order Restoration Council, or SLORC, as it is known, and the incarceration and torture of members and supporters of the National League for Democracy—which in 1990, of course, obtained over 80 per cent of the vote in democratic elections—the international focus has certainly been on this country.

The report on Thailand that we debated earlier dealt with one of the other aspects of this matter—the fact that ASEAN countries perhaps do not have the same stress on human rights that we have. It is something that cannot be run away from, it is something that must be acknowledged and that we must work with. I note that in this report, and I think it has bipartisan support, there are certain benchmarks that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) has indicated should be the guidelines for any kind of assessment of progress. It is all right to talk about constructive engagement and about progress that has been made. But, in reality, as we have been seeing in the newspapers in the last week, it really is not that patently obvious that progress has occurred.

We have had in the last week threats to the released leader, Aung San Suu Kyi. We have had very important announcements by a number of veterans of the independence struggle who have clearly identified themselves with the opposition and the need for further progress. We have had indications that the views of the opposition will not be given much consideration in the current movement towards a supposed constitution.

This report, as I say, goes to a few of the absolutely axiomatic issues in this matter. It says essentially that Australia must play a fairly important role in this region. It says that constructive engagement must be treated with care and that it should not be able to be manipulated by the Myanmar authorities. It looks at the disturbingly up-beat tempo of investment in the country and the reality that under the guise of this so-called constructive engagement there has been a fairly rapid growth of investment. Obviously that means that corporations of diverse nature start to have a vested interest in associations with the government and complicity in its future.

Table 6.4 in the report cites that investment growth has gone from $618 million in 1989 to just under $3 billion in 1995. The report also details the major countries that have been making that investment. In 1994-95, the United Kingdom led the way, followed by France, Singapore, Thailand and the United States. So there has been a steady growth in investment and it is occurring in a country that has very disturbing conditions. To cite a few of the views that have been put forward, Amnesty International in November 1994 stated there had been no fundamental change and that the government had reinforced its repressive hold.

Similarly, the US State Department stated that there was a pervasive security apparatus, selective restrictions on contact with foreigners, surveillance of government employees and private citizens and, in summary, harassment, oppression, detention and intimidation. Freedom House, in its assessment of countries around the world, gave it the lowest of its seven rankings. And in March 1995, Human Rights Watch/Asia, a creditable international monitor of human rights, spoke of the continued abuses across the country, forced portering—in other words, forced labour to help the armed forces—and reprisals against the civilian population.

There has been the forced relocation of between 500,000 and 1 million people. The Special Rapporteur for the United Nations has continued to expose the forced relocations from Yangon, Mandalay and Yan-bye. He has also detailed not only the very obvious restrictions and suppression of political activists but also these other facets of the country: forced labour, forced relocation and basic harassment of ethnic minorities.

The Burma Action Group in evidence before the committee specifically spoke of between 120,000 and 150,000 people being forced to work on the Ye-Tavoy railway, half a million people being forced to give three days a month for the restoration of the moat and the palace, 360,000 people compelled to labour on the Myangyan-Nahtogyi railway, and another 350,000 compelled to give their services for the Bassein Airport. There has also been a very big focus on the planned $1 billion gas link project involving the French company Total and the US company Unocal. The situation there has been that people along the route of that project have been moved from their houses and compelled to work on it.

There is widespread use of prison labour throughout the country and, in the same manner as the virtually simultaneous report on Thailand talks about labour conditions, a number of bodies have exposed the Myanmar government's very strong complicity in extremely poor international labour conditions. This report talks, on page 135 and afterwards, about an ILO report of the Committee of Freedom of Association and details specifically the activities of Myanmar's ambassador to the United States, other diplomatic representatives of that government and its own labour registration bodies in some cases, and, in one notorious case, kidnapping Burmese seamen who had complained about conditions. It details the very widespread international use of Burmese seamen.
For instance, the report talks about the MV Albatross, a Maltese flagship. On page 136, at point 92, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: Their December salary was paid three months late and minus overtime. Thereafter they only received cash advances representing a fraction of their true entitlement. Living conditions on board were appalling—they were rationed to only 15 minutes of fresh water for washing and bathing every five days, and were supplied with the barest minimum food to survive. Only 2.5 kg of meat were spread between 22 Myanmar crew. The rice was not full grain but the type usually used to feed livestock rather than humans. The men had serious worries about the overall safety of the ship. There was only one nine-year-old radio receiver working and the medical chest was almost empty in breach of international standards.
In relation to the Trans Dignity, the report spoke of the activities of the Myanmar government once those workers had returned to Myanmar. It says:
. . . their passports and seamen's books were confiscated by the Myanmar authorities as punishment for accepting the help of the ITF—
that is, the International Transport Federation—
and refusing to hand over their back pay settlements.

So it is not only the crude excesses of the military, their complicity in regard to prostitution in Thailand, their complicity in environmental destruction and their total control of large sectors of the economy; it is also that on the international front they are providing cheap labour, particularly in the transport shipping field.

PARA.TAB: They have had diplomats around the world—and this statement is supported unanimously by the committee, which has itemised and exposed this, and by other international organisations—who have become involved in supporting these shipping companies when employees have complained about conditions. They have been involved in extracting any wages that were recovered, and they have seized people's work permits. Quite frankly, a number of people who returned to Myanmar have not been heard of since by international unions.

The national convention, of course, has been pumped up as an indicator of the people's say in the process towards a new constitution. It is worth noting that, as of 9 January this year, of the 702 delegates, 550 managed to be selected by SLORC and, in reality, only one in seven were representative in any democratic sense. So this process towards a new constitution, this alleged movement towards democracy or some kind of progress on that front, is a total sham, essentially for international coverage. At 4.76 this committee says:

SPEECH.PARA: The current Burmese regime is a source of instability in the region. Its lack of accountability and legitimacy allows for corruption and oppression; there is no forum, independent of the government, to bring to account, consistently and impartially, those who, through normal human venality, abuse and oppress their fellow citizens.

So it is not only a problem internally for its people, it is a force of instability in the region. Of course, there have been concerns expressed by our diplomatic representatives, our foreign minister and by members on both sides of this House, about the degree of interaction—one might even go as far as `complicity'—by a number of ASEAN countries.

PARA.TAB: This report clearly reiterates the failure of the Burmese to sign a large number of important international conventions. The fact that they did not sign them shows their obvious unwillingness to adhere to these conditions. The committee states that the performance of the Foreign Minister, U Ohn Gyaw, at the United Nations in October 1994 was characterised by equivocation and contradiction.

The report reasserts the Australian perspective that the rights articulated in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights are universal, inalienable and indivisible. The arguments by the Myanmar authorities that they essentially have a Myanmar way, that there is a difference, and that they do not adhere to Western values, has fundamentally been rejected unanimously by this committee. This committee clearly asserts that there are no distinctions by creed, race or state of development.

I believe that this committee has come down with a report that hits at the issues. It says that we cannot sit back, we cannot worry too much about our associations with some Asian countries that might not be as forthright. Finally, at paragraph 5.12 of the report, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi is quoted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Many authoritarian governments wish to appear in the forefront of modern progress but are reluctant to institute genuine change. Such governments tend to claim that they are taking a uniquely national or indigenous path towards a political system in keeping with the times . . . It is often in the name of cultural integrity as well as social stability and national security that democratic reforms based on human rights are resisted by the authoritarian governments . . . It is claimed, usually without adequate evidence, that democratic values and human rights run counter to the national culture, and therefore to be beneficial they need to be modified—perhaps to the extent that they are barely recognisable.
She also said:

A nation may choose a system that leaves the protection of the freedom and security of the many dependent on the few; or it may choose institutions and practices that will sufficiently empower individuals and organisations to protect their own freedom and security.

The press coverage of the last week has clearly shown her continuing struggle and her unwillingness to comply with the requirements of SLORC. Obviously, this committee's report indicates bipartisan support for her role.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Mr Andrews) adjourned.
Debate resumed from 28 November, on motion by Mr Martyn Evans:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two decades after its passage through this parliament, the Family Law Act continues to be perceived as something which marked a turning point in family composition and interpersonal relations in Australia. Was it the important reform which Lionel Murphy claimed a decade after its passage, or was it a measure that transformed marriage into licensed cohabitation from which any party has the right to withdraw at will?

PARA.TAB: These questions have been debated for the last two decades and, no doubt, will continue to be debated. In many respects this parliament over that period of time has addressed those questions through a series of inquiries. A major inquiry was that of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act, which reported in 1980. A more recent inquiry was that of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues, which operated in the previous parliament and in this parliament.

Funding and administration of the Family Court of Australia is the third report of the current joint select committee. Much of the report deals with resourcing and administration of the Family Court and the structure of it. In short, the committee concluded that the court is sufficiently resourced, but could be more efficiently conducted. The committee also proposed a reordering of the management structure of the court.

In terms of funding, the court has been operating in a running cost environment since 1989-90. In the last financial year the net cost of services of the Family Court was $97.3 million, with a running cost budget in 1995-96 of approximately $67 million. The nominal Family Court running cost allocations from 1989-90 to 1994-95 have increased by 50.7 per cent with an average annual increase of 8.5 per cent. The real percentage increases over the same period are 36.8 per cent with an average annual increase of 6.5 per cent. The expenditure increases for the total nominal cost of the Family Court, which include property operating costs, for the same period are 70.9 per cent with an average annual increase of 11.3 per cent. The real percentage increase is 55.2 per cent with an average annual increase of 9.2 per cent.

The committee came to the conclusion that the court is adequately funded and that any changes in circumstances which may have an effect on its workload and may require additional funding should be negotiated with the Department of Finance. We were aware that the Family Court has a complex and difficult task but ultimately recognised that the court, like other budget funded agencies, must manage in the best way it can with the resources it has available. The committee does not approve of the Family Court's past record of overspending and its inappropriate management practice of utilising the facility of borrowing against future needs. The facility for borrowing funds should be used only in exceptional circumstances and should not be adopted as a normal management practice. Continual borrowing is analogous to a person living on their bankcard.

In relation to the matter more generally, the committee believes that the court would benefit from an in-depth outside evaluation of its management and financial practices, with its internal records open to full scrutiny. We have recommended that this should be done by the Auditor-General by way of an efficiency audit.

Turning to the management of the court, the committee does not believe the responsibility for the management and administration should be solely vested in the Chief Justice, who is assisted by the chief executive officer. Accordingly, the committee has recommended that the responsibility for the management and administration of the court should be vested in a collegiate body of judges of the Family Court and expressed through the rules of the court. The existing management structure of the court is unnecessarily complex and is not the optimum structure for the court. The complexity and duplication of functions lead to unnecessary expense, particularly in the form of travel and conferences. The complex matrix of management should be replaced by a centralised management structure utilising effective local regional personal management rather than the present top-heavy bureaucratic structure which is employed by the court.

We came to the conclusion that the Family Court is operating like a department of state rather than like a court. The court should be stripped of its bureaucratic and administrative layers and complexities. It should abolish its regional management and establish its principal office in Canberra. These are, of course, far-reaching recommendations so far as the structure is concerned. This was a unanimous report of the committee and we hope the recommendations are taken on board by the government.

Turning more broadly to the issues of family law, it is sometimes said that when an idea has gained general acceptance its time has passed. One limitation of the current inquiry, indeed of the act itself, is the concentration on rights without a corresponding emphasis on responsibilities. In particular, the emphasis remains on the rights of parties—that is, the rights of adults—to end a marriage. Yet research increasingly indicates that children can be the victims of the cultural change which occurred either because of or related to the passage of the Family Law Act.
Last year the Exeter family study in Britain challenged the assumption that children do not suffer greatly from divorce when it noted:

SPEECH.PARA: Previous studies have strongly suggested that it is parental conflict rather than their actual separation that is associated with poor outcomes for children following divorce. This has led some commentators to suggest that it is better to resolve a high conflict situation by ending the parental relationship than by allowing it to continue. This view, while not being widely promoted, has gained some credence as `accepted wisdom', and, indeed, many of the Exeter families who had divorced believed that their decision was in the best interest of the children as well as themselves. Data from this study provides some evidence that such a `justification' for divorce may be a misunderstanding of the reality.
The authors went on to say in their conclusion:

The findings from this pilot study indicate that although most children do not exhibit acute difficulties beyond the initial stage of family breakdown a significant minority of children encounter long-term problems. Compared with their matched pairs in intact families, children who had experienced their parents' divorce were more likely to report problems in key areas of their lives, including psychosomatic disorders, difficulties with school work and low sense of self-esteem. They were more likely to feel confused and uninvolved in arrangements about their future and to have lasting feelings of concern about both their resident and non-resident parents. Parental conflict and financial difficulties are clearly important features of family reorganisation that are associated with adverse outcomes for children. However, in this study it appeared that a more important adverse factor was the loss of a parent and the consequences, which included the risk that history would repeat itself with the breakdown of subsequent parental relationships.

That study reinforced work that had been carried out over a period of years, particularly by Judith Wallerstein in the United States of America, and therefore challenged some of the assumptions that underlie the legislation itself.

PARA.TAB: As Michael Duffy, the editor of the Independent Monthly wrote recently:

SPEECH.PARA: It is possible that children have been the great losers of the social changes of the past 30 years and that, as women were oppressed by patriarchal society, children are oppressed by the new order.
Recently, the Chief Executive Officer of the Family Court, Mr Glare, said that Lionel Murphy's vision of the court was flawed and naive. He said:

The thesis of it was the friendly, helpful, caring court and taking the fault out of it to get rid of bitterness. The fact is it doesn't, and the fact that they can't have a court blame one partner or other often creates a great deal of bitterness.

I recall that when the Family Law Act was enacted it was established on two pillars, those two pillars being one of rights and the other of responsibilities. The rights pillar is the right of a party to say, on the evidence of 12 months separation, that the marriage had ended and therefore they had the right to be able to walk away or to leave or to end that marriage. The other pillar is the responsibility which is set out in section 43 of the act to somehow seek to enhance family life and marriage itself.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, the late Lionel Murphy, in his second reading speech, made reference to this pillar of the Family Law Act when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: There are important provisions in the Bill for helping persons who contemplate, or have begun, proceedings under the Bill to achieve a reconciliation where possible, and for helping persons for whom a reconciliation is not possible to resolve their differences with the minimum bitterness and hostility. The reconciliation provisions extend to all proceedings under the Bill, not just divorce proceedings.

If one looks at the other speeches at the time by various members of parliament from both sides of the chamber, it was quite clear that one of the pillars upon which the Family Law Act was established by this parliament was that of responsibilities, not simply the pillar of rights. But, two decades after the introduction of the act, only one pillar, the one relating to rights, the one relating to the divorce of the parties, remains effectively as the operational basis of the legislation.

PARA.TAB: The neglect of reconciliation in particular has been something which has been commented upon from time to time. As long ago as 1982, a New South Wales judge described a section of the legislation supporting marriage as:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . propaganda contradicted by the substantial provisions of the act.
Speaking in 1991, the Chief Justice of the Family Court, Justice Nicholson, conceded the failure of the supportive provision when he said:

Originally it was thought that the court would play a role in the promotion of reconciliation, but the experience of the past 15 years has been that by the time that a couple approaches the court, there is little room for reconciliation, and such reconciliations that do occur are of uncertain and doubtful duration.
It is against that background that the committee has made some recommendations in relation to counselling, to alternate dispute resolution and to mediation.

PARA.TAB: The committee, basically, is of the view that the services of the Family Court, given the history of the past 20 years, should be reduced to its core judicial functions and that alternate dispute resolution, including mediation, should be pursued in the family law area in a community based program, or series of programs, rather than through the Family Court structure itself.

There is a provision in the act which provides some statutory requirement on the court to provide reconciliation. Given that that has not occurred, and it has been conceded by the court that that has not occurred, we have said that the legislation should quite clearly put that within the realm of various community agencies—the family life movement, Relationships Australia, et cetera—so that, with proper funding, they can pursue that. With respect to the conciliation counselling that is provided in the court—that is, counselling that is aimed at enabling the parties to achieve a divorce with less bitterness than might otherwise be the case—we suggest that that counselling, where possible, should be directed to agencies outside the court itself.

The effect of these measures would mean that the pure judicial functions that exist under the legislation would be retained by the Family Court. I refer to the things which were thought of as being important 20 years ago—namely, the responsibilities pillar. That pillar can be seen in terms of support for marriage and relationships, in terms of trying to enable people to enter into relationships on a better footing and, if there are difficulties in those relationships, to be able to resolve them with a view to trying to strengthen the relationship. That responsibilities pillar of the Family Law Act should be separated entirely in terms of the legislation. In that way, it can be given the degree of importance, the degree of support and the degree of funding which is desirable in the circumstances.

One hardly needs to repeat that there are various ways of measuring divorce in the community but it is generally accepted that the rate of divorce has increased about threefold over the past 20 years, and that the chances of a marriage succeeding have been reduced to about six in 10, over the lifetime of a marriage. If you look at a period of 25 to 30 years then it is expected that four in 10 Australian marriages will break down. Given that that comes at a cost of some $3,000 million a year to this community, it is something that this parliament ought properly have in consideration—and so, too, should the community. This will not be the last word on the Family Law Act. There will need to be some ongoing reviews of it because it is such an important matter for society and for individuals. I commend this report to all members and to the government. I hope that some of the recommendations are taken up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I would like to compliment the honourable member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans) who took over as Chairman of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues late in the committee's consideration of this report. I can only be very complimentary about all of the skills that he brought to bear as chairman of the committee. He certainly has a much less iconoclastic approach to matters than I do and I am sure that the committee members were very grateful for that. I would also like to compliment my friend and colleague the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) for his contribution to the committee. He has brought to the committee a longstanding interest and expertise, particularly his focus on trying to bring in prevention at a much earlier stage than currently, regarding government dollars. I understand that I am to be followed by the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams), for whom I have an equal regard. I have appreciated always his patient explanations of the law.

PARA.TAB: I want to say from the outset that, in a negative sense, this report does not go far enough for my liking. But, having said that, I think this is a very good report. I think it starts the platform of further reform in the Family Court area and I would urge all honourable members to read it.

I find it regrettable that this was always only intended to be a cameo report which briefly trailed over the information systems of the Family Court and gave yes or no answers to funding needs. For that reason, the committee really did not benefit from great public input as it had in its two earlier reports, the icebreaking report under Senator Jim McKiernan and the report in the child support area.

Notwithstanding that, this is an excellent report. I congratulate and thank all the acting secretaries of this parliamentary committee: Robina Mills, Claressa Surtees, David Wallace, Matthew Mason-Cox and, of course, Jane Vincent, who is away on leave. At various stages, these people acted as the secretary to the committee.

The honourable member for Menzies concluded by saying that this will not be the last look at family law, and I agree with him 100 per cent. However, I am not disappointed that the select committee is, in a sense, winding up. I believe that there is a need, certainly in the next parliament, to look at the community sector: how it operates and whether or not there are ways in which we can strengthen its effectiveness, notwithstanding the recommendations to increase its role that are contained in this report. I sincerely hope that there will be sufficient members around in the new parliament who would be so motivated to want to do that.

The family law area needs constant monitoring and finetuning, if not change. I will be very blunt. I think the Family Court expected quite a number of things to come out of this report, not the least of which was the call for increased funding. We have actually rejected all those aspirations that the court may have had. We reject the call for extra funding. We state that the court is adequately resourced. We reject the call for extra jurisdiction and, indeed, we break down the monopoly position of the Family Court in family law matters. We reject any call for more judges and we actually propose that extrajudicial registrars should be provided from within the existing judicial positions.

We strip the court of its dormant function of reconciliation or pro-active counselling. We can debate whether the court was adequately funded to fulfil this important role when it was set up 20 years ago. The truth of the matter is that, in 20 years, it has never allocated a priority to it. It is about time the parliament faced up to the issue that the court is not going to pick up this function. Yet this function is vitally important. We also attempt to strip or realign the power of the Chief Justice by recommending a more collegiate form of management for the court, which I am convinced will serve the court well in the future.

I want to discuss this touchy issue of reconciliation or pro-active counselling. The chief executive officer has appeared before the committee. He stated that the court does very well and that only five per cent of all cases that come before the court actually lead to a case before a judge in the court. This is a most deceptive argument, because it ignores the fact that many people get frustrated along the way and run out of money after having to spend awful amounts. There would not be a single member of the committee who did not think that we would be a lot better off if even just a portion of the money spent on private legal expenses were actually allocated to the children of these broken relationships and marriages.

I want to put on the record that I do not accept this five per cent figure as some justification for excellence in the court. I reject the proposition that breakdown will always be so traumatic and so emotional that we cannot do very much better. This is where I think reconciliation and pro-active counselling comes into play. At the very best, it will save some relationships; it will save some marriages.

A problem, in my view, is that we come up against some prevailing male taboos in that males are very reluctant to undergo counselling. We have to break down those taboos. Even where we do not actually save marriages—and it will always be the case that some relationships, some marriages, break down—we need to increase dramatically, in those that do break down and are dissolved, the degree of dignity of the partners, a regard for getting on with their own new lives, and particularly an acceptance of responsibility for any children in the marriage.

It is absolutely disappointing that so much government money is focused on the terminal end of relationships and marriages and so little is up front. Again I pay tribute to the honourable member for Menzies, who has always had a consistent attitude to that. By the committee saying that pro-active or reconciliation counselling should be a function placed in the community sector and funded accordingly, we are for the first time as a parliament really doing something very serious.

Other people have mentioned what really is the maladministration of the resources of the court: the lack of priority setting; the inability to come to grips with cost-benefit studies and apply that methodology to funding initiatives; the fact that new initiatives have been embraced without a commitment from the Attorney-General's Department or the Department of Finance to finance them; spending up the allocation of the court consistently so that each year it lives on its bankcard; and, last but not least, the reception of money from the Justice Statement such that it bailed the Family Court out of serious financial difficulties. These are all contained in the report, and I think they need to be addressed.

I particularly welcome the statement of the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) that he has already commenced to pick up the recommendation about having the Australian National Audit Office go through the Family Court. I hope the court and the Minister for Justice pick up the other recommendations as well.

I will address a couple of other issues. Firstly, the independence of the judiciary is a cornerstone of our democracy. In countries where this does not operate, the low quality of life and the lack of human rights are, unfortunately, the consequence. I think all members of parliament would wish to maintain and support the independence of the judiciary, but I am not convinced, at this stage, that transferring financial responsibility away from the Attorney-General's Department to the courts for administration is an aspect of this independence of the judiciary. I have an open mind about whether it should stay there or whether it may be better to return that function to the courts. It is something for the Family Court, in particular, to contemplate.

The other issue I want to raise is the fact that under the act the media are not allowed to report cases of the Family Court which would identify the parties. We took evidence in Western Australia that the import of that section of the act meant that it is almost impossible for the media to report cases which come before the Family Court. This has had a very unfortunate consequence because in no other court, with the exception of the Children's Court, is a court free from the glare and accountability that is associated with media reporting.

Others may say that they will report the sensational cases. That is true. Politicians could be victims of that. That is true. The court is a pressure cooker for a lot of the dissatisfaction that ordinary people have had—and, indeed, some learned people from the law have had—about the way the court operates. In a democracy it is not a good thing that we have such an act on our statute books. In any other court, applicants before the court can always put a case to the judge, based on merit, about whether or not names should be suppressed. I have sufficient confidence in the judiciary to suggest that I am quite happy to leave that discretion. We do not pick that up in the report. I just signal my dissatisfaction that we have not, and I hope it will be addressed later.

The other thing that I have already apologised for but I reiterate was that during the child support inquiry we got a lot of complaints about the issue of access, which is now called contact. I had always said that we would try to pick this up in the report. We have failed to do so. Many people will feel let down and I sincerely apologise for that. There is a great interest among members on both sides of parliament in the operation of the family law area. I am sure that they will be monitoring the implementation of reports, how well and effective they are and whether or not they are making a real difference. I hope in the future, if there is still the need, that issue will be picked up. I commend the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Family law is a very important issue in the community and although the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Certain Family Law Issues entitled Funding and administration of the Family Court of Australia will not be a best-seller, it may have greater significance in the future than meets the eye.

PARA.TAB: Preparation of the report was undertaken under what I regard as less than ideal conditions. The committee established in the 36th parliament, that is, the parliament which sat between 1991 and 1993, had this subject committed to it but, because of the width of the reference that was given to it to review the whole of the Family Law Act, this part was hived off and saved for a later report.

The committee commenced the hearing of evidence in November 1992 at the end of the term of the parliament and at a time when an election was imminent. When the committee was reconstituted in this parliament it was given the task of investigating the Child Support Agency, and the funding and administration provisions of the Family Law Act that had been saved from the previous reference were postponed until the completion of the CSA report.

The CSA report was a major job. It contained something like 160 different recommendations and took many months. There were thousands of contacts with people in the community regarding the subject matter and the report took a great deal of time in its settling. It is not unfair to say that the committee members were somewhat burnt out by the time it was completed.

The committee then turned its attention to this report, and even then there were problems. The member for Chifley (Mr Price), who spoke before me, was, at this time, chairman of the committee. Mr Price made a speech on 1 May this year which attracted the ire of the Chief Justice of the Family Court—I will say something about this in a minute—and caused some consternation among committee members. There was a lack of continuity in the secretariat staff in the latter stages of the committee's work. The chairman changed in June and the report was put together, I believe, in something of a rush at the end of this parliament. The circumstances were not ideal and, no doubt, the report could have been improved by a more focused and regular form of inquiry. However, there is a report and it should be considered on its merits.

The Family Court is basically a trial court and it has registries and courtrooms across the country. There are great difficulties in administering a court which has to exist under these sorts of arrangements. In the 1995-96 budget, the Family Court has an amount of $100 million budgeted for it, which is a very substantial sum. By way of comparison, the Federal Court of Australia—which, similarly, is basically a trial court and has registries and courtrooms across the country—has a budget of $37 million. There are nothing like three times the number of judges in the Family Court as there are in the Federal Court, which, of itself, raises a question.

The court has grown since it was established about 20 years ago and, in the course of this growth, a significant number of questions have arisen. These questions are to some extent for government and to some extent for the court to address. The questions are only partly addressed in the report. It is entirely appropriate for the government to ask why such a substantial sum is spent by the community in the resolution of the breakdown of marriage.

It is to be borne in mind in this context that the expenditure on the court is only a small part of the total cost of family breakdown within the community. The amount of public funds spent in the community for preparation of people for marriage and for support of the institution of marriage is minuscule by comparison. Even if one adds into this context relationships where there is no marriage but where there is a stable relationship, the amount of money spent is fractional in comparison to the money spent on marriage breakdown.

This report by the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues does not answer this question and, to this point, there has been no answer forthcoming from the government. There is a token recognition of the disparity in the government's recent Justice Statement, but this goes nowhere towards answering criticism which, I believe, is quite proper.

A question for both the court and the government to ask is why the Family Court has grown so much and why its activities are extending into areas which do not appear to involve the exercise of the judicial power of the Commonwealth. I am referring here not only to counselling—which seems to be a large part of the court's activities—but also to the various alternative dispute resolution mechanisms. The report points to a need to move some of these activities away from the court and back into the community. However, I regard the examination of these issues as only preliminary. The court itself appears to be not at all concerned that it is ceasing more and more to look like a court and that it is becoming, in appearance, more and more like an organ of the executive government.

Given the geographic spread of the court's facilities, it is appropriate to ask what the proper management structure is for the court. The report gives the committee's response to that, suggesting that the current regional arrangements are not the best alternative and that the traditional model of administration of the court, where the administration responsibility is vested in the college of judges itself, is more appropriate than the present scheme whereby it is vested solely in the Chief Justice.

That suggestion is not in any sense a direct criticism of the Chief Justice but, as a matter of principle, there are very good reasons which have been articulated by the current Governor of Victoria, the Hon. Richard McGarvie, as to why the college of judges rather than a single member of the court should be the body responsible for administration.

With the relatively new system of a one-line budget and the court having responsibility for its own administration, difficult issues arise as to the extent to which the government should intrude in the administration of the court and as to the means by which the court should be accountable to the public for the quality of its management. The report raises this question and proffers some comment on the issues but it does not provide a complete answer. That is a subject that I think needs further analysis, probably not only in relation to the Family Court but in relation to all courts having a one-line budget arrangement. I know that the Australian Institute of Judicial Administration has a particular interest in this subject.

I mentioned earlier that the member for Chifley had made a speech on 1 May on which the Chief Justice had commented. The member for Chifley knows, because I have told him, that I was going to say that I do not agree with the course of action he took. In his speech he was highly critical of the court in circumstances where I believe it was inevitable that the media would hear of what he said. He gave the appearance in my mind of having prejudged some of the issues that were before the court and he generated, I believe inevitably, a loss of confidence by the court that the committee would undertake its inquiry in a fair and objective manner.

Having said that in respect of the member for Chifley, I have some comments also on the response that was evoked. The Chief Justice wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), and I think the letter was made available publicly. It has certainly been referred to extensively by the member for Chifley in a speech he gave in the House on 28 November in the context of the second reading of the Family Law Reform (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1995. I regard the response of the Chief Justice as inappropriate. It was intemperate in its own terms and, I believe, brought the court and the Chief Justice right into the political arena.

In this age when the members of the judiciary are subjected to close scrutiny and unrestrained—and sometimes irresponsible—public criticism, it is very important that the court is appropriately defended publicly, particularly against unjustified invective. In the absence of action on the part of the Attorney-General or the legal profession in defending the court, I believe the court should defend itself publicly. But when a response comes from the court, that response should be compatible with judicial independence and objectivity and the maintenance of confidence by the community in the judicial system. The community must be confident that, in coming to court, they will get a fair, impartial, objective hearing and a just result. There is a serious risk of the loss of that respect and confidence if the sort of response that emanates from the court to public criticism is of the sort that one would expect to find in the political bearpit rather than by way of a dignified retort.

Having said that, I think that the problem was largely resolved by the promotion of the member for Chifley to the chairmanship of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and the replacement of him as chairman by the member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans), who, I must say, very quickly got on top of the subject.

In conclusion, let me say that, from my point of view, the report is not a blueprint. It does expose some community concerns and particularly some concerns felt by members of the committee as to the funding and administration of the court and it gives some pointers, some directions, for future reform. But I really regard it at this stage as a preliminary examination of what are in many cases very difficult issues. I look forward to this being regarded as only a first step.
Debate (on motion by Mr Melham) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR DEVELOPMENT COOPERATION AND PACIFIC ISLAND AFFAIRS

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 29 November, on motion by Mr Beazley:
That the House take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to express my thanks to the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney) for having laid down this report on the 35th conference of the South Pacific Commission in Noumea. The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland) and I were members of a parliamentary delegation that visited, with the minister, the South Pacific Commission and participated in its deliberations. Then separately—although the minister also visited Fiji—the honourable member for Macarthur and I visited Fiji from 28 October to 1 November. Our visit to the South Pacific Commission from 25 October to 27 October was really more as part of a parliamentary representation to the commission. There are a couple of aspects on that that I want to address briefly.

PARA.TAB: The first is that it is many years since I last attended a South Pacific Commission. The South Pacific Forum has adopted a much higher profile in recent years and it has become very much the body around which political debate takes place. On the last occasion when I attended a South Pacific Commission, it was there that countries such as Fiji and other members discussed quite significant issues that affected the future development of the region.

On this occasion, it was apparent that the South Pacific Commission has become far more oriented to aid and to the development of economic opportunities within the region. For that reason, I found it particularly interesting meeting those Australians who have been attached to the South Pacific Commission and to learn from those who are in our mission to Noumea—particularly the Consul-General, Graham Wilson, the vice-consuls and others—something of the Australian operations.

I have little doubt that a body such as the South Pacific Commission has a continued role. I wondered, after the establishment of the South Pacific Forum, whether perhaps the days of the commission might be finite, but I see a great advantage in having a South Pacific Commission which is able to debate and collate technical assistance for Pacific island countries and contribute to their economic and social development.

Our particular visit coincided with the election processes for the top three positions in the South Pacific Commission: the Secretary-General and the directors of programs and services. I was very pleased that Australia decided to field a candidate with whom I have been associated for many years, Dr Bob Dun. I first knew Bob Dun when he worked as a veterinarian at the Trangie Research Station of the New South Wales department of agriculture. That was in the days when, as a young lawyer, I decided to become a farmer. I remember going to courses in genetics at the UNE and going around trying to learn. At the time the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) and I were both involved in the University of New England. Bob Dun was one of those young vets who was able to help me considerably in understanding why, if you joined an Angus to a Hereford, the progeny had white faces, and matters of that ilk. Bob Dun subsequently did his doctor of veterinary science degree and is now one of the world's leading geneticists, quite apart from the experience he has had in AusAID in administering the Australian aid program and elsewhere. It was he who was selected to be the Australian candidate.

The election was quite an interesting process, and I confess that there were times when we wondered just how the vote would eventuate. It went through a series of negotiations before the actual ballot and then, on the day, there were two other candidates contending for the position. In any event, Dr Dun was successful. The other two candidates, one from New Zealand and one from Fiji, no doubt had their merits; but, from Australia's point of view, as a major contributor to the South Pacific Commission, it was important to have somebody with the background and experience of Dr Dun to ensure that the whole of the development of the South Pacific Commission aid program and administration retained both conformity with other similar organisations and the ability to use its not insignificant funds to best advantage.

The positions of director of programs and director of services were filled by very capable candidates, too, from the Solomon Islands and Guam, respectively. I think it is going to be very interesting to see how the SPC performs in its new format. I certainly see that the budget subcommittee and some of the budget analysis that we discussed at the commission will help to ensure that there is better use made of the funds spent. In its magnificent new `upturned canoe' venue in Noumea, there is no doubt that it is an organisation which is well housed and is now being well administered.

One trusts that the SPC can help the development of the South Pacific nations, which do have great challenges. Many of them are monocultural states with economies based on coconut and fishing or copra and fishing, and it is very hard for them to diversify to any degree. It is particularly important when nations such Australia and France—which is another major contributor in this region—allocate so much to the aid programs that they should be well administered.

The one real disappointment I had at the SPC meeting was that Britain is withdrawing. Britain has made successive major blunders in its handling of affairs in our part of the world. This is too narrow a debate to enable me to develop the point but, since Britain took the policy years ago to withdrew east of Suez, it has progressively pulled out of a region where it has enormous financial investments. I find it quite paradoxical that, at a time when Britain is pulling out of Hong Kong—in 1997, of course, China resumes control of that colony—we are going into a phase where Britain is going to be represented in the South Pacific Commission by its residual colony in the Pacific, Pitcairn Island, which has all of 84 inhabitants.

I cannot think of anything more stupid than for Britain's ambassador in Fiji to attend next year's South Pacific Commission not to represent Britain but to represent Pitcairn.
