Britain does have a role. The South Pacific Commission benefits from having the United States represented at this forum by a very distinguished American. It is important that the European countries, who for so long have taken a great deal from their colonies in this region, should maintain a commitment to help these nations develop for the future; so I was very sorry that Britain was withdrawing.However, the South Pacific Commission enters the next year with a strong management team and, apart from the British withdrawal, the era ahead with Dr Bob Dun at the helm will be one of great interest and, I hope, of significant achievement.

From there, the honourable member of Macarthur and I were members of a parliamentary delegation to Fiji. I wanted to say a little on that because it seemed to me that this was an appropriate way by which we could report to the parliament on developments in a country that has been very close to Australia, where many of us worry about constitutional evolution, where the processes of democracy are not necessarily seen as we see them, and where the Rabuka `revolution' of some years ago caused a great deal of angst in Australia—and still causes worry—because of the extent to which it seemed to be based on a racial prejudice which, for all that one might have sympathies for the Fijian people, leaves a concern about the large number of people of Indian extraction who have contributed so much to the economic development of the island. Sugar is still very important there.

Our program started with our arrival at Nadi. We had lunch on the first day with the President of the Senate, Ratu Tu'uakitau, at the Fijian Hotel. From there we went to Suva where we met the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Jai Ram Reddy, a man with whom anyone who has met him could not but be impressed. But, as he said, the paradox of his position as leader of the opposition is that he can never be prime minister. That seems to be an extraordinary situation, where the leader of the opposition in a parliamentary democracy—or a country that presumes to have a parliamentary democracy—cannot be prime minister. The challenge for Fiji is to develop a situation where they do accept the processes of parliament and the electoral system which allow whoever it might be to be the prime minister if they are elected.

The following day in Suva we met a series of people at the Parliament House. We were escorted by Mr Victor Rigamoto, the Secretary-General of the Fijian parliament and my colleague the honourable member for Macarthur presented some books to the parliamentary library on behalf of the Australian parliament. Since our visit I have arranged through the Clerk of the House of Representatives to send a number of books on our procedures and practices to the parliament of Fiji. They are essentially interested in following our Westminster style traditions and one would hope that they can continue to do so.

We were hosted to a lunch by the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Dr Kurusiqila, who was a very redoubtable rugby player in days gone by. In the afternoon we went down to meet Mark Halabe, who runs the Mark One Apparel garment factory. He is an Australian of some considerable success here who has a garment factory in Australia and in Fiji. He told us of some of the worries that he has, yet he did say that the productivity here was higher, although the costs were higher too. Mark has done a very good job, in my view, in the development of his factory there. The conditions for his work force were excellent and the stability was good. He deserves to be commended and I hope he continues to achieve economic success.

The following day we met Mahendra Chaudry, who is the General-Secretary of the Fiji Public Service Association and is another very distinguished Fijian. He is of Indian extraction and is the leader of the equivalent of our public service association. He was a very impressive man. Following that, we met the person I will always remember as being outstanding amongst those we met—Mrs Nazhat Shameen. She is a person, I suspect, of Sri Lankan extraction and is the Director of Public Prosecutions. She is a highly educated young lady, a brilliant lawyer, and we have offered her any assistance we can give to keep in contact with law development and processes here.

She told us of a number of draft laws that she is developing to try to help the Attorney-General in the exercise of his function. Many of them relate to areas which are already legislated in Australia and I would hope that she could feel herself able to contact either her counterpart in Australia or, through the honourable member for Macarthur and me, the Australian Attorney-General's office so that we can help in the task of trying to ensure that the laws in Fiji are developed on lines that meet the general requirements of a changing community.

We were hosted to a lunch by Mr Greg Urwin, the Australian High Commissioner to Fiji. Mr Urwin has only recently taken up his post and he and his wife are doing an excellent job. I would like to particularly thank Mr Urwin and his staff. During the course of our visit we did have a great deal of assistance from officers in the Australian embassy and I would like thank each of them. Carl Ungerer was attached to us for most of our visit, and was very helpful in every way. Both the honourable member for Macarthur and I found that it was well worth while.

Relations with Fiji are important to Australia. It is sad that there is still doubt as to whether a true democratic government will be introduced after the constitutional commission has finished its process. That is a matter for the Fijians themselves to determine. I am sure that all members of this parliament would be prepared, on a bipartisan basis, to assist Fiji's evolution towards democracy, or the development of its laws. My wife, Rosemary, and I enjoyed the opportunity to again see a little of that wonderful country.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a great pleasure for me to be part of the delegation representing Australia at the 35th South Pacific Conference and also, as the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) said, to visit Fiji as part of an Australian parliamentary delegation. It was my first trip to the South Pacific. In more ways than one I found it to be very much a learning experience about the culture, the politics, the economics and the general dynamics of that particular region.

PARA.TAB: As the honourable member for New England pointed out, we started out on the eve of the conference with the opening of the new building of the South Pacific Commission—as he described it, the `upturned canoe'. It is an impressive structure, built to take account of the climate and of local traditions. It is certainly an improvement on what they had before. In this case it was money well spent by the commission, although we have heard criticisms about other aspects of its management in the past.

This is one of the reasons why Australia and New Zealand ran candidates for the secretary-generalship of the organisation. As the member for New England said, that particular election was an interesting process. I recall reading about it the week before in the Sydney Morning Herald. Australia thought that it would probably have the support of most countries to get our candidate, Dr Bob Dun, elected. There were reported to be some deals being done between New Zealand and England surrounding CHOGM and it was expected that it would be a very tight result.

It was a very interesting process. It was not quite like a ballot, as we know it, in Australian politics. It was a diplomatic exercise where it seemed that everyone was at pains to avoid at all costs an actual ballot on the floor of the conference. But because it was such a close contest, after a long-drawn out process of lobbying and an interesting form of diplomacy—one that I had never seen before—that is exactly what happened. There was a ballot on the floor of the conference, involving three candidates from Australia, New Zealand and Fiji.

It was an unforgettable couple of hours while this process was discussed. After a fairly close contest and a tense few hours, Dr Bob Dun was elected. I believe, as the right honourable member for New England said, that he will be an excellent choice as Secretary-General of the South Pacific Commission.

I would like to congratulate our Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney) for his efforts in representing Australia at that conference, and particularly for his lobbying efforts—along with the people from DFAT and AusAID—in securing Dr Dun's election. As I have said, it was a fascinating process, the like of which I had never seen. But more power to the people responsible; it was a pretty good lobbying exercise. Congratulations to the minister, and also to the various diplomats and public servants involved in securing that result.

I thank the officers from foreign affairs and AusAID. I also thank the consul general and his office in Noumea for their support and assistance. It was certainly a pleasant and successful trip to Noumea. There were no hitches and we were very well looked after by our hosts and those responsible.

We also went to Fiji. On the way there, unlike the honourable member for New England, I had the opportunity to visit Vanuatu for about four hours. I was on a different flight. Even though it was such a short visit, it was very pleasant and a bit of an eye-opener. I thank the High Commissioner of Vanuatu, Mr Peter Shannon, for his hospitality. I certainly enjoyed myself for those few hours.

We arrived at Nadi in Fiji. I did not really know a lot about Fiji, although, of course, I recall the Rabuka coup in 1987 and the overthrow of the democratically elected government. I was rather concerned when I learnt in more detail about the current constitution, its review process and its likely outcome. As we discovered, the constitution is now based on racial lines: the Prime Minister has to be an ethnic Fijian. As the honourable member for New England pointed out, the present leader of the opposition, Mr Reddy, is in that position by virtue of being the leader of the largest Indian based party in the parliament, but, of course, he cannot be Prime Minister. I think something is not quite right about a parliamentary system in this situation.

We met Mr Reddy and the leader of the Fijian labour party, who, as the member for New England pointed out, is the president of the biggest public sector union, the Public Service Association. We had an interesting talk with both of those people. They lead the two major Indian based constituency political parties. In some ways, they were philosophical about the proposals. I got the feeling from our talk with these people, and with others, that they were not very optimistic about the likely outcome of the constitution or its effects. It is of some concern when one of our traditional near neighbours has a constitution based on racial lines, which results in clear divisions in the community.

Another concern was Fiji's economy. Although Fiji is in a fertile part of the world with great economic potential, especially in agriculture, it is not living up to its potential. It relies on its sugar industry, which is still very much based on old technology with labour-intensive work practices. It relies on an agreement for preferential treatment with the European Union. That runs out in the year 2000 and Fiji might have some problems re-negotiating that agreement in this era of free trade and so-called level playing fields, et cetera. Fiji has the potential to do a lot more with its agricultural industries, and it is not doing it. This was an area that we commented on, and others commented to us about this, during our visit.

As I said, we met a number of people. I would like to thank the Australian Ambassador Dr Greg Urwin and his staff, particularly Mr Carl Ungerer, from the embassy in Fiji. We were also very well hosted by Mr Victor Rigamoto, who holds the position of Secretary-General of the Parliament, which I understand is a bit like our Clerk of the House of Representatives and Clerk of the Senate rolled into one—a bit of a Mr Fixit. It is a very powerful position in Fiji. I actually referred to him as the town clerk of Fiji because the role is almost like that of a general manager of a large council. He is obviously a very central figure in their administration and he is also a wonderful person and an excellent host. It was a pleasure to meet him.

We also met the Speaker of the House of Representatives, as the member for New England pointed out, made a presentation to him and the President of the Senate, and invited them to visit Australia and our parliament in the near future. I know they have both been here in recent times and of course they are welcome back again. As the member for New England also pointed out, we met the Director of Public Prosecutions. That was a last minute-arrangement, but it was very interesting and I endorse the sentiments of the member for New England about Fiji's Director of Public Prosecutions. She is a very impressive young woman and one of probably not very many women in positions at the level in Fiji. Fiji's legal system is in good hands if people like her are around for some time.

I must admit that I was caught a bit short in having to make this speech. My notes are not here and I was given 10 minutes to get here. I had thought we would be discussing this this afternoon. Having said that, I would again like to thank all the people involved, including the member for New England, who was a very interesting and wonderful companion on the tour, along with his wife, Rosemary. I would also like to thank the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney) and his staff, the staff of DFAT and AusAID, and the consul-general in Noumea and embassy staff in Fiji. I would also like to thank the High Commission in Vanuatu for the assistance provided on this trip. As I said, it was my first trip to the Pacific and, hopefully, not my last. It certainly was an eye-opener and a learning experience for me and I am very pleased to have taken part.
Debate (on motion by Mrs Sullivan) adjourned.
Debate resumed from 29 November, on motion by Mr Beazley:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quick Mr H.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this opportunity to speak on this very fine report entitled Global change in Australia's overseas aid program which is a ministerial policy paper and the 6th annual report to the parliament on Australia's development cooperation program. In what is possibly my last chance in the current parliament to speak on an issue, I welcome being able to speak on an issue that is very dear to my heart—that is, Australia's overseas aid program and how it fits into the changes taking place in our world.

PARA.TAB: It is a shame, in a way, that such a valuable report is being debated in this place and that only two government members have the opportunity to discuss the vital issues raised in the report. Hopefully, those of us who return in the next parliament will take up many of the issues and they will be debated and followed through. As I said, it is my last chance to speak on this issue and it is pertinent that I relate where I am coming from, why I am involved in the whole issue of Australia's overseas aid program and how it impacts on people in my electorate.

I well remember growing up in the era of church sponsored overseas aid, especially from the perspective of what the Presbyterian Church was doing, as my late father was a minister in the church. As a child I remember meeting missionaries from what seemed the far-flung areas of the Pacific Islands, China, Korea and many of the African countries, and hearing stories of life in those remote villages when those missionaries visited our churches and convinced people to contribute to the missionary campaigns.

In a way, they whetted my appetite to hear and read more on the issue. Being an avid stamp collector, collecting stamps from those remote regions only added to my interest. Then I was fortunate to have as a role model in my early high school years a patrol officer from New Guinea. He had a remarkable impact on my life and I aspired to emulate him when I left school. Years have passed and I am now in this place representing constituents from the Franklin electorate.

In those many intervening years I have maintained my desire to visit areas of the Third World, as we call it. I have continued to be an active member of the many organisations throughout the world that play a vital role in ensuring that people from those developing countries are given as many and varied opportunities to obtain adequate health, medical, legal, educational, agricultural and social services that we take so much for granted.

In my former life as a school teacher, I saw my role as one of challenging students to think of what their role might be, what role their parents might have, and what role their community and their nation had in addressing many of these global issues, even though they seemed so far away and so remote from the local school classroom. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The rapid rate of change over the last ten or so years has had an enormous impact on the need for development assistance.

We are lucky that many of us are now living in an era when the Cold War blocks have melted away and countries are emerging from behind the wall of failed ideologies. There is a real opportunity for countries to now rationally discuss development issues. We are finally able to settle and focus on the real heart of the matter—what best suits each country if it is to achieve sustainable and equitable economic growth, and how donor countries can best support that process.

PARA.TAB: As is stated in the report, there are several key factors resulting from the end of the Cold War era. Massive changes to international trade brought about by the Uruguay Round agreements and the establishment of the World Trade Organisation have had dramatic impacts on many of the developing countries that neighbour us. Then there are the positive and negative influences flowing from the internationalisation of the world's money markets, and no doubt my esteemed colleague the member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) will be talking on some of those, because I know he has a keen interest on those.

Regional and ethnic clashes in Africa, the former USSR and the eastern European countries are a downside to the end of the Cold War. In many cases, they have created demands for humanitarian assistance, for refugee resettlement and for peacekeeping operations. Television coverage of these conflicts, now beamed into our houses ad nauseam, has focused citizens and their governments and the aid agencies to sit down and try and address these key problems. These have inevitably led to a transfer of resources away from what we had planned as longer-term developmental priorities.

There has been a realisation by most within the international aid sector that in order to halt ongoing outbreaks of civil disturbance, which will consume an ever increasing aid dollar, there needs to be put in place a proper structure which will diminish the need for peacekeeping and emergency relief measures. We have only to look at what has been happening in Africa in the last 12 months or so to see that, unless we do put in place these proper sets of structures, we will be continually revisiting the same parts of the world.

The final challenge to governments comes from a range of issues which flow from the globalisation of our world—something that we thought would never happen in our lifetime but is now taking place so rapidly with the breaking down of political boundaries and the movement of people. There are the issues of HIV-AIDS and other communicable diseases, economic migration, drug trafficking, global warming, access to water resources and the deforestation of large areas of the world. My constituents say, `Where does Australia fit into this most complex of worlds and what does it really have to do with me in the town of Huonville or parts of Hobart?' I say to them that we have an obligation, as a group of citizens, as a state and as a country to focus on all of these issues because they will, they do and they are impacting on our way of life.

As has been stated by the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney) in this place many times, Australia is fighting above its weight in the area of international development aid. I would like to think that AusAID, and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, is playing a key role throughout the world in addressing many of these issues.

I have been fortunate in my brief time in this place to be part of a House of Representatives inquiry into Australia's overseas aid in the health area. I soon realised that this area of aid is a very complex and involved thing. It involves the problems of where we send it, who is responsible, and the development, between the key players and the government, of a proper meshing of all the programs that are being run by the various agencies and NGDOs to ensure that people in various parts of the world—whether they be in the Asia-Pacific region, Africa or in Asia itself—are able to have their issues addressed.

Following on from that, I was fortunate to be part of a parliamentary delegation to PNG, the Federated States of Micronesia, the Marshall Islands, Samoa and Tonga. I was able to speak, at first hand, to ministers from the various countries, aid workers, volunteers, church groups and villagers. I was able to gain an insight into just how effective and ineffective, in some cases, our aid really was. I came to a realisation that, unless aid is project specific, we are not really going to gain the maximum benefit from the dollars that we put into these various aid agencies.

This is a very good report. It is very detailed. In section II it comes up with a very detailed outline of developments in the Australian overseas aid program in many countries. I recommend that all those who are interested in this issue of aid read it.

There is another chapter in section III which raises the issue of where we go next—the future directions. It raises such areas as human rights and peace building—and one only has to remember the key role that Australia is playing in the UN in the whole area of peacekeeping. Other issues are broadening the development debate in Australia, technology, the civil society, private sector development and labour standards, and the issues of debt and the environment, which my esteemed colleague will speak about after me. There are a huge number of issues that we need to focus on.

Australia is doing a fantastic job in this area. I feel proud to be a member of the government because the Australian Labor Party has involved itself very largely in the aid program. I know we have been focusing on a whole lot of other key issues, but we have not forgotten the aid program and the need for our party and our country to get involved in this key issue.
The last page of the report identifies, in the conclusion, some key things that I would like to put on the record. In the last sentence of the second last paragraph, it says:

SPEECH.PARA: By striving to alleviate poverty, a root cause of instability and human suffering, the aid program is making an important investment in our future security.
It continues:

There are those in Australia and overseas who want to reduce aid programs . . . And under the Labor Government there will be no turning back from engagement locally, regionally and internationally in working for a better world, for all citizens of the world.

From my brief time in this place, I think that sums up the Labor government's commitment, not only to its own citizens, but to the citizens of the world. I would like to place on record my deep indebtedness to the commitment of the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney). He has visited Tasmania several times and spoken to aid agencies there. His is not an easy ministerial portfolio, but he has fought for the whole area of international aid, and I commend him and AusAID for the wonderful work that they are doing. When I come back in the next parliament, I and many others who were involved in this issue will continue to fight for a just and equitable share of the Australian budget for many of these programs. Finally, I commend the report to those in Australia who are involved in the whole issue of Australia's overseas aid.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two central points to be made as background to the discussion of the Australian development cooperation program report entitled Global change and Australia's overseas aid program. The first is that there has been a very substantial improvement in living standards in many developing countries—in most of them, in fact—during the last two or three decades. This improvement is partly due to the effectiveness of development cooperation programs but is principally due to the countries' own efforts; and that is very encouraging. At the same time, it is also true to say that now, after three or more decades of substantial development, there are still an estimated 1.3 billion people living in absolute poverty and the need for development cooperation is as great as ever.

PARA.TAB: A lot has been learnt during the past three decades about the kinds of policies which will most effectively contribute to development within developing countries, and aid is now being very effectively targeted in ways that I will come to in a minute. But the need for the aid program is as high as it has ever been, and the reason is partly that there has been very rapid population growth within developing countries. Some countries have moved well away from needing aid, and many of those in our region—such as Korea, Taiwan, Singapore and Hong Kong, which all used to be aid recipients a couple of decades ago—are now rapidly growing, wealthy countries in their own right and are themselves starting to give aid to others. Other countries still have major problems of poverty, despite relatively rapid economic growth; and Indonesia, which is our closest neighbour, and Papua New Guinea, the Pacific Islands and the countries of South Asia are very clearly in that category.

It is very encouraging to see this excellent report by the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney), the sixth report in a series which began in response to a recommendation by the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs Defence and Trade in a review of the aid program. One of our recommendations was that there should be an annual statement to parliament on the principles, approaches and policies adopted by the Australian aid program, and that opportunity should be given to debate such a statement in parliament; and we have been given that opportunity today. I congratulate the minister both on producing the report and on the quality of the report. It is a fine report because it looks well into the future and brings up to date the principles that should be guiding our development cooperation program.
I principally want to look to the future but I want to make a couple of remarks about current activities.

First, it is very good to see that the aid program is being increased. In the last budget, the increase in real terms was $25 million, an increase of 1.6 per cent, which means that Australia will this year spend 0.33 per cent of GNP of aid. That, of course, is well below the UN target of 0.7 per cent. It is below our performance of a decade ago, well below that of two decades ago, and well below the average of OECD countries. I am disappointed that the statement trots out the misguided figure of 0.29 per cent for the weighted average of OECD countries, a figure which is quite misleading because it weights aid contributions by the GNP of contributor countries.

The very large contributor countries—particularly the US—which are mean in the extreme and which are cutting their aid most rapidly have undue weight. Those countries which are most generous—such as Scandinavia, the Netherlands, Germany and France—all give well above 0.29 per cent. In fact, several of them give closer to one per cent or 0.8 per cent. Such countries are given less weight, and so it is a very misleading figure. Taking a non-weighted, standard average, the figure is something closer to 0.45 or 0.43 per cent.

Australia is well below that figure, and that is something for us to be ashamed of. Nevertheless, in a very difficult budgetary situation, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs did battle in cabinet and achieved an increase in the percentage of GNP as aid, and I congratulate them on that. I am very glad to see Minister Bilney in the Main Committee with us.

I want to concentrate principally on the third section of this excellent paper, because it takes the framework and the concrete elements of policy beyond what has existed before. Section 3 begins with a recognition of the budgetary constraints which all donor countries are feeling, but it then goes on to talk about how we maximise the effectiveness of our aid. It draws attention to the fact that aid cannot simply be considered in isolation from other areas of policy, but that it must take account of programs which will maximise the impact on human rights as well—and not only civil and political rights but economic and social rights too. Section 3 also says that the aid should take account of security issues, and should look for means of improving human rights in all possible ways.

The paper goes on to talk about the contribution of aid to peace building, to the avoidance of conflict and the minimising of conflict once it has occurred, and about issues such as the institutionalisation of human rights, constitutional development, the strengthening of justice systems, and the encouragement of effective early warning systems. All of these are very important means of improving the quality of governance in ways that will also empower peoples so that development can be more effective and more equitably distributed.

The paper discusses the importance of broadening the development debate in Australia. A theme that I, amongst others, have taken up continuously for 20 years is the importance of development education to ensure that the whole Australian community has the opportunity to understand the aid program, its rationale and its importance not only in moral and humanitarian terms but also in terms of it being in our own interests to see countries in our region growing effectively and equitably.

The paper mentions a number of means that are being used to stimulate the development debate in Australia: expanding research, increasing teaching about development in schools; research on the causes and effects of global poverty and ways of reducing it; and so on. I was very glad to see, in particular, the reference to the AusAID initiated research program being built up.

I have other subjects that I suggest might be taken up, in addition to those that are listed. The subjects that are listed include the impact of the Uruguay Round of trade liberalisation, reforms on Australia's food aid program, an analysis of the New Zealand experience with the migration of Pacific Island nationals, the implications for Australia's relationship with Pacific Island countries and a review of Japan's aid program. These are all nicely targeted, valuable studies.

But there are many other issues that could be taken up in such a research program. One area that has been particularly neglected in Australia is the damaging effect on developing countries of instability in the international financial system, and ways of reducing that instability.

Other topics include the development, and the importance of developing, global public goods. We live in a globalised world, as this statement very effectively articulates. The response to that is inevitably going to include the provision of certain types of public goods internationally and cooperatively by countries acting together. There needs to be more research in Australia on that very complex and important issue. There are already good examples of that kind of cooperation in telecommunications and in civil aviation, but more is going to be necessary in other areas such as reduction of financial instability.

The statement goes on to talk about technology transfer, and ways of increasing use of appropriate technologies and high technologies in developing countries. It has an excellent section on support for development of the civil society in developing countries. It offers ways of building up more honest and accountable governments and encouraging the expansion of the non-government sector, including not only obvious non-government organisations in the development area, but chambers of commerce, trade unions, the media, support for establishing legal systems and for the rule of law.

These are all absolutely vital issues in any well-functioning society. In some countries in our region they are now well entrenched, but in others they are not. Right on our doorstep in Papua New Guinea, those activities are still relatively lively, but need support in order to maintain and strengthen their position.

There is an interesting section on the private sector. It is very important to find ways of enabling the private sector—through foreign investment, trade and technology transfer—to more effectively involve itself in development within developing countries. I was slightly surprised to see a reference to India being keen to study our approach to privatisation. I do not think our privatisation approach has been particularly worthy of emulation, but that is just a point of emphasis.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not criticising the government?

—No, absolutely not. But it is important to find ways of working cooperatively with the private sector. It is a refreshing emphasis in the aid program that this matter is now being given more attention. There is a very good section in the statement on labour standards. I will not go into it in detail, but it is thoroughly worth studying by anyone interested in those issues. It talks about the importance of strengthening regulatory frameworks, and of addressing all kinds of issues to do with training and trade union development, occupational health and safety, and minimising exploitation of child labour.

PARA.TAB: There is an important section on debt—which could have gone further. The issue of debt is now under very active study in the international community. The World Bank has a very important internal study under way, under the direction of the new managing director, an American of Australian origin, Jim Wolfensohn. The outcome of that is not yet clear, but what has been talked about seems to be excellent, and is something that we should strongly support. There are other important sections on the role of agricultural research, on the difficulties caused by rapid urbanisation and of the importance of giving attention to the environment in our aid program. This is a most valuable report.

I conclude by emphasising one of the final sections on the role of the United Nations, and the importance of reform of the UN. I was actively involved in the World Summit for Social Development, which concluded successfully with an excellent statement and a program of action on policies for reducing poverty, for increasing employment opportunities and for strengthening social solidarity. The conference made a whole series of recommendations about ways in which UN effectiveness could be increased.

It is impressive to see that Australia contributed $83 million of its core aid funding to the UN last financial year. We should be proud of that. We should look for ways to increase it, while also increasing the effectiveness with which those funds are used within the UN system. It is vital that the Economic and Social Council be built up and become more effective. It is vital that the UN resources be strengthened. We must keep the pressure on the United States of America to discourage its appalling cuts in support for the UN. It is not even keeping up with its basic obligations, let alone anything else. It cannot be left to medium sized countries alone, such as Australia and Scandinavia, to support these activities in the UN.

There was a very refreshing debate during the 50th anniversary celebrations of the UN about ways in which its effectiveness could be increased. We will continue to have a leading role to play in ensuring that that reform takes place. I congratulate both the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs for their excellent statements and their roles in all these tasks.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BILNEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In closing the debate, I would like to offer an apology, first of all, because I was not able to be present for the remarks of the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Quick) who spoke earlier in this debate. I had a meeting with the Vietnamese delegation that went overtime, but I was able to catch the last part of the member's speech on television, I was able to hear most of what the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) said. I am very grateful to both of them, not just for their contribution to this debate, but also for their contribution to the wider debate about aid in Australia. They have both been extremely supportive and informed participants. I am greatly indebted to them for the remarks they have made and for the continued interest they take in the aid program.

PARA.TAB: There are a few things I want to say in responding to the points that have been made in the debate, principally by the member for Fraser. Given that this will be my last statement to this parliament on the aid program, it has been a matter of great pride to me that I have been able to preside over what I believe is one of the best aid programs in the world, one which has sought to respond to changing circumstances in a very rapidly changing world. Trying to turn around the aid program quickly is like trying to turn around the Queen Mary because so many of the commitments that are entered into tend to be multi-year commitments and one must carry through with them.

The great emphasis that we have given to health and population activities during the last two years is such that we now devote over seven per cent of our program to these commitments, and the proportion is growing. Last year expenditure on those activities went above $100 million. That is something we can be proud of. The increasing emphasis we have given to micro-credit in providing poor people, usually poor women, with the means to alleviate desperate poverty, is something that we have got into in a larger way. Provided the pilot programs that we are running succeed, we can see that expanding a great deal in future.

While there has always been an emphasis in the program on education, we are now shifting away quite rapidly from very expensive tertiary education provided in Australia—necessary and important as that is—to the provision of basic education, particularly for women and girls. This is one of the best ways to bring about genuine development.

The member for Fraser mentioned the emphasis on the environment. That has certainly been something to which the program has responded. Last year, expenditure on environment related programs directly was of the order of $160 million. As well, the whole program is measured against a set of environmental standards which means that we do no harm to the environment and mostly do good.

Over the three years that I have been in charge of the aid program, there has been a considerable shift in geographic emphasis. We are now much more involved in Indochina, as Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam emerge from a very oppressed and unhappy history into playing their full part in our region. The aid program is doing its damnedest to help them with that.

There has been an unfortunate change in emphasis—I say unfortunate when I refer to the amount of resources we are now devoting to humanitarian emergencies of one kind or another—unfortunate because I think many of us had hoped that with the end of the Cold War there would be an outbreak of peace. Unfortunately, the reverse has been true. There have been some tragic and appalling humanitarian catastrophes around the world to which our aid program has responded as best it can. I hope the day arrives when we do not have to spend money on this sort of thing. Something very decent in us responds to humanitarian catastrophes, and Australia has gone into places like Rwanda, Somalia and Bosnia through the aid program and in other ways to deal with those terrible emergencies.

The member for Fraser spoke very well of the need to widen the aid debate in Australia. He has always been on at successive ministers in that regard. While the amount of money that we are spending now on development education has not risen by much—it has more or less doubled, I think—we are trying to spend that money much more strategically. I am sure I give away no secrets when I say that we are trying to spend money on getting people in the schools and getting curriculums changed so that people learn about development issues in the schools.

My hope is that, by infecting children in schools with the desire for a better world through the aid program, the same sort of momentum and passion will be built up about those issues as was built up in the last 10 years about environmental issues. If that happens, then I think governments of whatever stripe will be powerless to resist the demand of people for—
Mr Lindsay interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —For decency, as the member for Herbert rightly interjects. Part of that changing world is the new world of trade. One of the things that I have asked AusAID to look to in the next budget is how we can assist the countries of our region in particular, but also more widely, to deal with the new disciplines and rigours that are going to be placed on them by the coming of APEC and the new world of the World Trade Organisation. Let us be clear: there will be, if not winners and losers, big winners and less big winners in those new regimes. Through the aid program we need to look at how we can mitigate the pain for those who will suffer and smooth the transition to better societies which I believe freer trade will bring—but there are going to be some hiccups along the way.

PARA.TAB: The member for Fraser alluded to the levels of development assistance around the world. What the Republican controlled Congress is threatening to do with the United States aid budget in respect of particular programs is an unhappy circumstance. Population activity is a likely casualty, the World Bank is another and multilateralism in general is a target. Around the world one sees aid levels declining and it is very hard, with the best will in the world, to keep up the levels in Australia when all around us aid levels are dropping.

I hope that is a temporary phenomenon, because aid programs have a great deal to do. I welcome the fact that private investment flows are, in many parts of the world, helping to make up for a decline in ODA levels. But there will always be things that aid does which private investment cannot do. I hope we can look towards a better performance by some of our partners in that regard, thus keeping up our own efforts.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't come with clean hands. You never mentioned targeting.

—What I will say in response to the interjection is that I think we have done pretty well over the years. Going back a few years, there were some large decreases, for which I do not propose to apologise. But I do not think we have had too much to be ashamed of over the last three years.

PARA.TAB: I want to pay tribute to the professionalism of the AusAID offices who have been responsible for devising and implementing the aid programs over recent years. They are, in my experience, very dedicated and committed people. I have made it my business to be closely involved both with people in the higher and middle levels and with people who have just joined AusAID from the junior levels. I must say that theirs is a pretty classy act.

I do not believe that our program would be nearly as good were it not for the fact that these people are very professional and very dedicated and would not do other things if you paid them more. I know that many of them are constituents of the member for Fraser, so it gives me no pain to say in front of him that that is the case. I hope that he will continue to look after their welfare in other ways, as well as looking after the welfare of our aid program in the gadfly way that he has.

I thank both them and the two members who have contributed to the debate. It is a pity that someone from the other side did not contribute to that debate. If I may be allowed to be a bit political in this committee, I suppose that it reflects the fact that they do not have an aid policy, as far as one can discern, except to cut the aid vote—something which would be a tragedy.
Debate (on motion by Mr Nehl) adjourned.
Debate resumed from 23 November, on motion by Mr Beddall:
That the House take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In talking to the APEC statement, I would like to say, first of all, that I welcome that statement and am in strong agreement with it. I see it as another step forward in developing our trade relations in this region. But the big test is still ahead of us: we have to actually translate the good intentions and the good work that has been done so far into real results.

PARA.TAB: If we look back, we find that this is a situation wherein the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is progressing the work of the former Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke. It is built on some very solid work that was done earlier by the previous Prime Minister, Mr Fraser.

But we have also got to put it against this backdrop: Australia's share of East Asian imports has dropped by 20 per cent in the last 10 years and, since 1983, Australia has lost market share in China, Hong Kong, Japan, Malaysia, Singapore, Taiwan and Brunei. In fact, Australia's merchandise trade surplus with the APEC region has declined from $5.8 billion in 1990-91 to $1.8 billion in 1994-95.

However, it is particularly pleasing to see that the APEC agreement includes comprehensive coverage of all sectors, which means that agriculture is very much on the agenda. This brings Japan, South Korea and Taiwan to accept the need to address the matter. It also brings China into the camp of trade liberalisation.

It is also important to note that the agreement covers all measures, both tariffs and non-tariff barriers. As the Prime Minister has stated, an example of a non-tariff barrier is that customs procedures can add 10 per cent to the cost—and many of the main impediments are non-tariff barriers.

It is heartening to note that the Prime Minister has noted in the APEC statement that the common harmonised system of tariff classification is to be worked on for 1996 and standard electronic customs message system and pilot mutual recognition agreement in the area of standards are to be introduced by 1999 and 1997 respectively. There is also a commitment to abolish export subsidies by the year 2010.

The pressure this agreement should place on the United States to address these areas, which would, in turn, one would hope, put pressure on the European community, is a positive aspect. There could be some good spin-off effects in world trade, not just in the APEC region. If the APEC agreement does reach its objectives, it will benefit all commodities: grains, meat, dairy, wool, cotton, rice, sugar and horticultural products, such as dried fruits, grapes, citrus and apples.

It has been stated that there is potential, if we can follow this through, for Australian farmers to generate around $2.9 billion worth of exports. These figures have come from the National Farmers Federation, which points out that that amount is in addition to the extra $1 billion we hope to see come from the Uruguay Round of the then GATT agreement. The agreement has yet to be translated into results but the potential appears to be there for some major benefits. As has been pointed out, those benefits are potentially three times as much as will come from the liberalisation of trade through the World Trade Organisation.

However, our attention should not be diverted from the domestic issues and problems. If the benefits are really going to be translated back to our producers, particularly our farmers, we have to look at domestic cost structure problems, an area that the government seems to have been rather reluctant to take up the challenge on in recent times. I refer to problems in relation to the waterfront, industrial relations and, of course, excessive red tape.
I refer to the speech of the President of the National Farmers Federation last week. In his address to the council he said:

SPEECH.PARA: There needs to be much greater commitment from government to advancing the domestic reform agenda. In my view, the government has hit the wall on reform . . .
He could not put it much more bluntly than that. He went on to say:
It—
that is, the government—
is suffering from reform fatigue and its own agencies are providing the evidence.
Referring to a report of the Bureau of Industry Economics he said:

The recent report . . . has highlighted widening performance gaps in Australia's infrastructure, especially in transport and power. This gap is a serious issue for all businesses, not just for farmers.

I would like to now talk about some specific issues that still have to be resolved. The first one is the proposed APEC Food and Agribusiness Task Force. I strongly support this move, as I believe it offers the chance to have the debate on our terms, particularly in light of the Food and Agricultural Organisation's summit to be held late next year. We have to get the discussion going on the whole question of food security because much more detail is needed. It really is important to see how the food security issue is going to be pursued. One would hope that we can start to move away from the subsidies to agriculture to much freer trade in this particular area. If we can look at food security in this new light of getting away from the subsidies, not only can Australia then extend the supply of agriculture and the products but we will be able to provide them much more cheaply.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to overemphasise it, but I cannot overstate the need to address some of the domestic issues. I will quickly give you one example of where the government has really got reform fatigue. The overview in the Industry Commission report entitled Meat processing that was brought out in April last year says:

SPEECH.PARA: This inquiry has found that despite some recent improvements, Australia's meat processing industry operates at significantly higher cost than processing industries of most countries with which it competes. It has also found that Australian meat exports have been losing market share in almost all our major export markets.

That is a really damning comment on the whole question of the government's approach. The significant point is that that report came out 18 months ago but what have we seen since? We have seen a government, as the president of the National Farmers Federation pointed out, that has reform fatigue.

PARA.TAB: Turning to the food and agricultural task force, I think it is very important that we should know more about it. In particular, we want to know who the members are going to be and what the agenda will be. The government ought to answer this. The Prime Minister has stated that he will be writing shortly to his APEC colleagues. I challenge the Prime Minister to release the details of what he intends to raise with them, because this will throw light on what is going to happen.

The second issue which I believe still has to be resolved is the action plan for the ministerial meeting to be held next year in the Philippines. It is terribly important that agriculture be kept at the top of the list because there is a real fear that the removal of trade barriers, particularly as they apply to agriculture, could be left until towards the end of the first period of 15 years. In terms of the action plan, it is very important that the government keep agriculture at the top of the list and up front. This is obviously going to be very much a challenge for the incoming government in the next parliament.

The third issue that requires a lot more work is how to link the APEC agenda for freer trade with the World Trade Organisation's agenda in its coming rounds, particularly with its first meeting coming up in December next year in Singapore. The question really has to be how Australia, with the Cairns Group, is going to use APEC to get the new round of the WTO going and to ensure that it is comprehensive and that it does include agriculture. In other words, we need to keep agriculture fairly and squarely at the top of the agenda. This is a major issue that still needs further work, and there is certainly no room for complacency.

I would like to add another issue for consideration in the whole question of trade. Further questions that cannot be ignored include the possible effect of the continuing friction between the United States, Japan and China on market access, which is going to be a significant issue in the future; the moves by Japan, Korea and Taiwan—which are probably also going to be supported by China and Malaysia—to quarantine agriculture as a sensitive sector from the liberalisation process, which is a major issue; and the reluctance by the United States to accept the fact that each economy takes decisions individually rather than across the board.

In conclusion, I believe this meeting is a significant and welcome step forward. If trade liberalisation can be realised, as has been put forward in the Prime Minister's statement, it will have very important and beneficial effects for the Australian economy. However, I would like to make sure that we keep this in some perspective, particularly given the effusive comments that the Prime Minister has made in his statement. I refer to a couple of editorials on the APEC agreement from newspapers in other countries. Firstly, Japan's most authoritative newspaper, Nikkei Shimbun, in referring to the APEC Osaka declaration, says:

SPEECH.PARA: We have a strong feeling that by using such vague language and by going without an element of compulsion the declaration has run away from dealing with difficult problems such as how to ensure implementation of liberalisation and comparability of measures taken by member nations . . .

I would have thought those words would have been of concern to all members. Also the Wall Street Journal derided the declaration as `a representative work of vague, bureaucratic language'. We have got to realise that this does raise some very serious questions. In particular, I wonder whether in fact the Prime Minister has been completely frank and honest when he said of the declaration that `You don't get it more solid than that' and that `It never gets as good as this', and made various other comments.

PARA.TAB: Nonetheless, I think it is very important that we do get all members of APEC to support this outcome and deal with it in a spirit of enthusiasm as strong as Australia's. We also have to take into account what we have experienced in some of these discussions, and I come back to the Uruguay Round where we saw a very significant slippage in a round of discussions that was supposed to take four years. It took seven years, and of course we are still to see the full benefits of the agreement that came under the World Trade Organisation.

This statement certainly does give some heart to the exporting sector of Australia, particularly in agriculture, but the benefits are still to be realised and it is going to require a lot of hard work and a lot of determination. I believe that the incoming government is going to have to continue to pursue this with the same vigour as it has been pursued by the current Prime Minister and by the former Labor Prime Minister, Mr Hawke—and I also mentioned some of the earlier work that was done by the former Fraser government. I think that all of this has contributed to our seeing a move, hopefully to be translated into action, towards seeing much freer trade in our Asia-Pacific region.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is fairly obvious that APEC is important to Australia and I share some of the sentiments of the honourable member of Wannon (Mr Hawker), especially his hope that the United States and the Europeans will see the example that has been set here—although I would not put too much store on editorials in the Wall Street Journal. I also share his hope and, indeed, his belief that agriculture should be kept at the top of the agenda.

PARA.TAB: But then, these people cannot help themselves. Before they leave their home every morning, they take a little tablet or something which says `Give the unions a bash.' Here we found it again—

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't mention unions.
—No, I know, but by implication—

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Newell)—Order! Members will not debate across the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were talking about the waterfront. It always amazes me that, when people here talk about the waterfront, the implications are that, if we could only get rid of the old waterside workers, all would be well. The waterside workers, now the Maritime Union of Australia, are only one part of a whole cog that makes up the waterfront. What we really should be doing is getting those farmers who are sending their produce through the waterfront to get the cargo there on time.

PARA.TAB: A report was debated in this very chamber yesterday—Warehouse to wharf. I have attended a couple of seminars on this issue in the last couple of months. In fact, at the last one that we held in Sydney dealing with that report, the exporters did not even bother turning up. Everyone on the waterfront blames everyone else and everyone protects their own little bailiwick. Okay, there has to be reform on the waterfront but it has to go right across the waterfront—the exporters, the whole thing. The problem with the waterfront in Australia is that it has been a closed shop in every section for far too long and everyone has been intent on blaming everyone else instead of looking at their own failure to come together in a cooperative manner and do something about it.

I do not want to get into an argument about everything the honourable member for Wannon said, because I agree with much of what he said. The member for Wannon spoke about the reform of meat processing, but it seems to me that the real tragedies in the meat industry in Australia over the last few years are the subsidisation of meat and the substitution of meat. It is not the workers who slipped a bit of old kangaroo steak in there and passed it off as first-class beef. Some of the export firms did this.

We have had two scares with the export of Australian beef, the first one being a couple of years ago when it was found that, in the United States and, indeed, in Japan, kangaroo meat had been substituted for fine beef. If there is one thing that will frighten a Japanese buyer away it is a whiff of scandal about anything. The Japanese are going mad about red-back spiders at the moment, and this situation will have an impact on our trade with Japan. Fruit fly in the mangoes in North Queensland and the whiff of a bit of Skippy being thrown in instead of bully beef terrifies the Japanese. Tremendous damage has been done to our meat exporting industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —And pesticides.

—And pesticides. They love these, don't they? They are absolutely terrified by a hint of pesticide. People talk about what we should do with our meat industry, but the most important thing that members of the National Party and others who are closer to the meat industry than I am can tell their colleagues is, `Hey, chum, let's leave Skippy out in the paddock jumping about. Don't slip it in as a bit of beef going to Japan.' Skippy has got a place in Australian industry, but it most certainly is not in our beef export industry.

PARA.TAB: As a middle power in international relations, Australia can be justifiably proud of the outcome of the recent APEC leaders meeting in Osaka. Australia can be proud that we have provided leadership to the world in trade liberalisation—one of the most difficult areas of trade—and in the opening up of world markets. I am interested that Australia's involvement dates back to Malcolm Fraser. I did not think it went back quite this far, but who am I to argue?

APEC is, without doubt, the key regional organisation for coordinating the development and growth of the Asia-Pacific region into the next century. The process of establishing APEC as the key regional organisation began in Seattle in 1993 when, on the initiative of the Prime Minister, it was suggested to other APEC leaders that an annual leaders meeting be established. The Indonesian leaders meeting produced the Bogor declaration which committed APEC economies to the goal of free and open trade in this region.

Two planks were set for this goal to be met: the free and open trade goal was to be met by industrialised countries by 2010 and by developing countries by 2020. With the goals declared at Bogor, the Osaka leaders meeting produced a plan of action which would show how APEC economies would implement the free and open trade goals.

As the Prime Minister said in his statement last week, Osaka is an outstanding success for Australia and all our objectives were met. Australia wanted a plan of action from this leaders meeting, and we achieved it. Australia wanted all 18 APEC economies to sign the declaration of free and open trade and investment in the region, and we achieved this. Sometimes it is easy to dismiss these summit meetings as being all pomp and ceremony and with little substance or resolution of the issues.

Nobody can, with any credibility, foster this view of APEC. Concrete achievements have resulted from APEC. Japan will accelerate its Uruguay Round tariff reduction commitment on 697 items, including textiles, chemicals, steel and non-ferrous materials, by approximately two years. Everyone thought that the Japanese were going to be the real problem. Hong Kong will bind at zero a further five per cent of imports in addition to Uruguay Round tariff bindings, as well as deregulating its banking services.

Canada will exceed its Uruguay Round commitments by reducing tariffs on 1,500 items. It will extend its preferential tariff systems and extend NAFTA preferential treatment of investment to all WTO members. Indonesia has an important tariff reduction program which extends to 2003. It has also accelerated its Uruguay Round commitment to eliminate non-tariff barriers. Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, Brunei, New Zealand, China, South Korea, Chile and the United States of America have all given similar commitments.

Australia has offered to accelerate commitments which we have already made. At Bogor, APEC leaders committed themselves to removing all trade barriers within 25 years. Realistically, this will never happen, but the target of removing most or many trade barriers is more than achievable. Osaka was the beginning of implementing the commitments established in the Bogor declaration. The Osaka action agenda sets principles which will underpin the process of trade liberalisation in the Asia-Pacific Region.

Eight principles have been agreed to, and are designed to set broad parameters within which APEC's liberalisation and facilitation program can be implemented. These principles are GATT and WTO consistency, comparability, timing and standstill—which refers to refraining from increasing existing levels of protection, flexibility, non-discrimination and comprehensive coverage. The central achievement for Australia was that all sectors and issues will be covered by these new principles.

Agriculture is now firmly on the APEC agenda. Agriculture is one area that has consistently missed the boat when countries have negotiated trade liberalisation and open markets. Australia has the most efficient agricultural sector in the world. Our farmers and their produce are competitive with farmers and produce from Europe and Asia. I assume that Australian farmers will be feeling very content with the Osaka results. It now enables them to plan confidently for the opening up and liberalisation of the huge markets in this region.

In establishing principles Osaka has also established the process for trade liberalisation. Leaders directed ministers and officials to immediately begin the preparation of concrete and substantive action plans to be submitted for assessment to the l996 ministerial meeting in the Philippines.

Overall implementation of the action plans will formally begin in January l997 with an annual review. Ministers have been instructed to engage in a collective confidence-building effort to facilitate exchanges of information, to ensure transparency and to work towards the achievement of comparability of respective action plans. This is particularly significant, given that no country will be prepared to make serious cuts in trade barriers if that country believes that other countries are not going to do the same.

APEC economies have emphasised that opposition to an inward-looking trading block, and are committed instead to firmly maintain open regional cooperation. I agree with the Prime Minister that the regular involvement of the leaders of APEC economies gives the meetings an authority and purpose that cannot be matched—with no disrespect to ministers—by a meeting of ministers alone. The Prime Minister should be commended on his initiative and for his subsequent campaign to ensure that the leaders are fully involved and have a stake in the result. At the Osaka meeting the leaders urged other WTO members to match the efforts of APEC. That is something that G7 members could not bring themselves to do earlier this year.

As well as agreeing on the principles of trade liberalisation, a number of important trade facilitation measures were established. These include greater cooperation among customs agencies, agreement on how product standards are to be used in excess, work on common approaches approving product standards for food, toys, cooperation over standards for telecommunication equipment and collaboration over human resource management issues. While these are not as valuable or, indeed, as sexy as cuts in trade barriers, they are nonetheless important because, for example, customs procedures alone can add 10 per cent to the cost of doing business and, although tariffs within the region remain high, many businesses suffer because of impediments in the non-tariff areas.

Modelling by the Office of National Assessment and the Industry Commission, while backing up earlier conclusions, also suggest that, when the full effect of the Bogor commitments flow through the income of APEC members, this will increase by 3.8 per cent or by $745 billion. For Australia this means our real incomes will rise by 6.8 per cent or $40 billion when all the effects have flowed through. This can be expected to generate something like 500,000 new jobs over the course of the liberalisation program.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I am preparing one of the famous Hollis information kits on the Osaka APEC meeting for my constituents, which I am happy to send you a copy of. The kit will provide them with readily available information on what was decided by the leaders of APEC economies and how Australia and the region will benefit from the long campaign that Australia has led to free and open trade. I commend the Prime Minister's statement to the house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neville Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the outcome of the APEC summit at Osaka this month where the Asia-Pacific leaders recommitted themselves to the goal of free and open trade and investment in our region by the year 2020. While this basic commitment was established at the Bogor declaration 12 months ago, the momentum of APEC continues to grow and Osaka was an important step along an often rocky road to trade liberalisation. The APEC action agenda agreed to by the 18 nations represented at Osaka provides a blueprint to achieve this trade liberalisation and trade facilitation in the Asia-Pacific area. It sets out the broad direction and mechanisms to achieve such free trade. However, the real test for APEC is converting the words into action. I will talk about that later and illustrate with some things from my electorate.

PARA.TAB: Trade liberalisation and better trade relations with our neighbours has been an objective of recent Labor and coalition governments. In response to the ministerial statement on APEC by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the goals of APEC are shared in common by both sides of Parliament.

It is also not just a recent phenomenon, as some may wish us to believe. One needs only to look back to the trans-Tasman CER agreement with New Zealand under Doug Anthony and Malcolm Fraser in the early 1980s for evidence of that bipartisan commitment to improving trade relations and eliminating trading barriers with our neighbours.

PARA.TAB: However, the real difference in political terms will come in how well the Australian economy can be managed to adjust to the changing circumstances to enable our exporters to take full advantage of the benefits of free trade. It will be our response to APEC where the difference will be made.

We know the benefits of APEC are many. As the Prime Minister and other commentators have already pointed out, there are potentially very substantial benefits to flow from APEC, not least of which is a $40 billion a year boost to Australia's national output and the possibility of the creation of 500,000 jobs by the year 2010. The benefits include $25 billion in tariff cuts and $15 billion to be saved by reducing non-tariff barriers such as varying standards for industrial products and clashing customs regulations.

Within my own electorate of Hinkler, the growing industrial city of Gladstone is set to benefit most from freer and more open trade in the Asia-Pacific region. Already Gladstone is a major exporter to the Asia-Pacific region, principally with the export of its vast coal reserves from central Queensland. The Gladstone Port Authority's coal handling facility currently handles around 24 million tonnes annually, rising to 30 million tonnes within the next four years. There are plans to eventually increase its capacity to 45 million tonnes, which the Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall) claims will make it the largest coal loading facility in the world by tonnage—which is an extraordinary thing, no doubt. The minister predicts there will be a continuing strong demand for coal exports, especially in South-East Asia, where coal is needed for power generation. He cites Thailand, which plans to build one power station a year for 15 years, requiring a new mine each year to supply coal to fuel those power stations. Again, that is an extraordinary potential.

Gladstone also is a major producer and exporter of alumina and aluminium products. According to the 1993-94 report of the Gladstone Port Authority, the port exports 2.7 million tonnes of alumina to Canada, China, New Zealand and the US, and 166,000 tonnes of aluminium to Japan, Korea and Taiwan. In the future Gladstone is set to become a major potential producer and exporter of another light metal, magnesium. From aluminium and magnesium, of course, flows the potential for alloys. A $50 million joint venture between Queensland Metals Corporation and the CSIRO is working on developing the process to make magnesium metal and magnesite mixed from the Kunwarara deposit near Rockhampton. The decision on where to locate the commercial smelter will not be made until 1997-98.

Gladstone is also emerging as a major producer of other export commodities, such as chemicals, cement, woodchips and, very interestingly, ice-cream sticks. It is not popularly known that Gladstone makes 1.3 billion ice-cream sticks a year, 70 per cent of which are exported.

TALK.START.PARA: —And chopsticks.

—The chopsticks are on hold, but it is an industry that could go ahead, and with this APEC thing, as I have said to the general manager of that firm as recently as today, that potential needs to be reinvestigated. He pointed out to me that they do come up against some very great difficulties. For example, various tariffs, taxes and duties mean that they are paying 30 per cent extra to get their products into Malaysia, 30 per cent extra to get them into Thailand and 25 per cent extra to get them into Indonesia. It will be interesting to see how all those nations embrace APEC and whether those tariffs, barriers and so on fall away.

PARA.TAB: The other thing he mentioned to me as a great challenge—and I do not want to be partisan in this debate, but, in the light of recent events in industrial relations, the thing that really stands out, he said—is the perception in Asia of the poor performance of Australian wharves. I know that the government claims that this has been improved considerably, but the perception still remains that our facilitation of export is not reliable. He said that affects him—someone who is selling only ice-cream sticks. There are also plans to develop a container facility at the port of Gladstone.

Elsewhere in the electorate, we have industries such as beef, sugar and horticulture. As you probably know, Bundaberg is one of the largest producers of horticultural products in Australia, and at times even tops Bowen as Australia's leading tomato grower. We have had some very interesting developments in that field. Currently we export over 200,000 cartons of tomatoes, largely to New Zealand, Hong Kong and Singapore. SP Export in particular are looking at the markets in Taiwan, South Korea and Japan. The barriers they see have come from quarantine and artificial trade barriers. They are looking forward to APEC breaking down those barriers and giving them a greater opportunity.

Another interesting industry in my electorate is Wide Bay Brick. You might say, `Surely no-one in Australia exports bricks.' But, indeed, this firm does. This is the largest privately owned brickworks in Australia and it exports three million bricks, mainly to New Zealand and Japan. It is also looking at markets in Taiwan, Korea, Hong Kong and New Caledonia. It has problems with trade barriers too, especially in Malaysia with its high import duties. It also has a problem with the freight component, which comes back to the wharves and, to some extent, shipping.

Another firm that is quite different again from small crops and bricks is Electra Breweries. That firm currently produces just under a million cartons of brewed ginger beer, 20 per cent of which is exported. New Zealand is the biggest market and it receives about 200,000 cartons of Bundaberg ginger beer every year. It has started trial marketing into Korea, Hong Kong, Singapore, Taiwan and the US.

In a lot of cases, there are different customs barriers, labelling laws and import duties, and that makes it particularly difficult for Electra Breweries to penetrate those markets. To come back to Thailand, the various duties that apply mean that the firm's product in Thailand will cost nearly twice as much as the comparable local product. So there is a big challenge there for us to try to cut down on those barriers and on our own export facilitation costs.

The APEC commitment not only provides Australian exporters with great opportunities, but also with great challenges. Just because the Asia-Pacific region is committed to moving towards freer and more open trade, that does not necessarily mean that Australia will automatically increase its market share in the region. I have just illustrated this using a number of firms in Gladstone and Bundaberg as examples. In fact, our trade performance in the APEC region has actually been falling over the past decade or so—that is, falling in relative, not gross, terms.

For example, our exports to APEC countries have roughly doubled from $US13 billion in 1985 to $US26 1/2 billion in 1993. However, in that time the APEC import market has almost trebled and our share has slipped from 4.09 to 3.09 per cent. In other words, the market has trebled but our share has dropped. So, in relative terms, we are not performing as well in Asia as we might. If we had been able to hold our share of the market in the APEC region, that would have been worth another $US9 billion a year to us at present in export earnings. That is a lot of money to forgo.

Similarly, if Australia is to take advantage of the emerging APEC opportunities we must get our domestic economic settings right. While I am on this point, I would like to quote Don McGauchie of the National Farmers Federation. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Trade liberalisation is surging ahead, but domestic reform has hit a brick wall and the Federal Government must act quickly if Australia is to remain competitive.
He went on to say:
It—
meaning the federal government—

has effectively put reform on hold until the next election. It has no stomach for the major tasks of reducing the current account deficit, tax reform and introducing true flexibility into the labour market.
As I have said, I will not be partisan about that, but I think we should reflect on it a little because it is an important component.

PARA.TAB: The waterfront, as I said before, is a very important aspect of Australia being competitive in the APEC region. A recent Bureau of Industry Economics report said that the waterfront remains one of the key problem areas for Australia, with long and variable unloading times and high prices characterising the movement of containers through our ports. The report found:

SPEECH.PARA: Port charges to load or unload a container at Johore in Malaysia were only $85—one third of those at Adelaide . . .
That is Australia's cheapest container port—again, a great illustration of the point I was making earlier. The report also found:
It took twice as long to move a container at Adelaide as at the best comparably sized offshore port—Zeebrugge in Belgium.
That is another illustration of how we have to lift our act.

PARA.TAB: While our coal handling ability at ports such as Newcastle and Hay Point was as good as any in the world, the BIE report identified telecommunications, electricity and rail freight as areas of the economy that were marring our performance and producing lower productivity. In short, I think we could do it better.

As I tracked through a number of industries in my electorate, the thing that came through from many people—and, again, I do not want to be unduly critical—was that they thought Austrade could lift its game in the area of market intelligence.
