For example, one company that I spoke with sought from Austrade the range of competitive industries in a country in South-East Asia and Austrade missed the largest group in that country. That cost this particular industry in my electorate a lot of money because had they been alerted to that fact they could have done better. The other point I made, and we have talked about it in this address, is that the smallest unit product in my electorate, ice-cream sticks, is already affected by the perception of Australia's waterfront performance. I think there are a number of areas there on which we should reflect as we move into APEC.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always of interest to look at the way in which the international associations of which Australia is a member—or those that represent Australia—report back to the parliament on where they are, where they are going and what they have achieved. There is little doubt that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) sees himself rather large in international gatherings of this character and would rather that others see him as he sees himself. I hate to tell him but I do not think that is so. I think there are a few problems in this international perspective. There are a few aspects of this APEC forum that illustrate that and I want to address those now.

PARA.TAB: Having said that, I think due credit must be paid to the Prime Minister and to successive Prime Ministers—to Bob Hawke, to Malcolm Fraser, and way back to Bob Menzies and John McEwen who started the whole process. If we look at where we are going economically, Australia has been helped enormously by moving away from total dependence on the United Kingdom and the UK-Australia trade agreements. The fact is that Britain had a very good capacity to be able to take advantage of Australia's developing economy.

When Europe expanded and the Treaty of Rome began the European Community that it is today, and Britain quite properly decided she was going to become a member, of course, the UK-Australia trade agreement was concluded and Australia had to turn elsewhere. We have been very fortunate that, over the years since that 1956 signing of the Japan-Australia trade agreement, since the wheat deals were first negotiated with China, there has been a tremendous economic development in the economies of each of those countries to our north and also the relationship between us. If we look statistically, however, we will find that, sadly, Australia's proportional share is declining. Although in volume we are increasing, our proportional share is in fact less today than it used to be. That is a matter which needs to be identified and we need to see what steps can be taken to redress it.

Interestingly, part of the problem that I see for this APEC meeting is that what we need to do in any of these international groups, as far as possible, is to be inclusive not exclusive. Unfortunately, the Prime Minister—not just with respect to the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell)—tends to feel that the more he can keep himself a little isolated from everybody else, the better, and that is my worry with APEC.

APEC would be better if it were a wider organisation. I think it is sad that, after this third meeting, they are still quite content to look at the 18 members that there are today and say, as the Prime Minister says, `We know where we are going and we are quite content.' I think it is important that we look at to what degree we can bring other countries of Asia—and, perhaps, some more of the countries of the South Pacific—into the APEC group. We could have all of the spectrum, if you like. The big, populous countries, such as India, the countries which are struggling to find a new way, such as Russia, and smaller countries, such as Fiji, all have roles.

I am not sure that the membership of 18 is where it should stay. Indeed, it is a forum for Asia-Pacific economic cooperation. Let us face it, `Asia' embraces more than just the countries around the Pacific. I think the countries of the Indian subcontinent have to be encouraged to turn to this part of the world to try to develop commercial relations, so that we can expand our relations in that area. I hope that the membership of India is considered before long.

I feel the same about Russia, having visited Vladivostok, Port Nachodka and a few other such places in the east of Russia. We need to make sure that they are allowed to consider themselves a Pacific power. In the days when I visited, they were still part of the Soviet Union, and I believe there has been little change. Essentially, most of the major decisions are still taken in Moscow. Moscow is a long way from those centres on the Pacific coast, and I think it is very important that we encourage those countries which have some association with that area to starting thinking of the Pacific. I would be all in favour of including Russia too.

I know of the problems. I know it is not going to be easy. I know the achievements of the last three summit meetings mean that the countries which are there feel that they have got a relationship which can be properly developed if there is a benefit in it, as there is. All those things need to be acknowledged. But I do not think we should look at the APEC group as being inclusive only of those who are present members. That was the first of the points I wanted to make with respect to the progress of this third meeting in Osaka.

The next point that strikes me about the achievements or otherwise of the Osaka meeting is that it is worthwhile that those goals towards breaking down tariff barriers that were set in Bogor have virtually been confirmed. I was talking to some people after the Bogor meeting—I think I was in either Thailand or Indonesia—when it occurred to me that whatever goals might be set internationally, and whatever we might think of the outcomes, we need to see outcomes in the terms of each of the participants. In fact, that point was made by the Malaysian trade minister after this Osaka meeting.

Often, those achievements are seen differently by other countries from the way we see them. That was certainly true of the Bogor conclusions. Many countries, looking at the Bogor agreement and reading the proclamations made by Paul Keating, would have said, `Trade is going to be totally free in this region for the developing world by 2010, and for the developed world by 2020.' But, having talked to the representatives of other countries—as I am sure I did in Indonesia, as well as in Thailand—I know there is a real problem. The interpretation of the Malaysian foreign minister, a very articulate lady, suggested that they also had reservations.

Everybody is going to try and put their own interpretation on it, so I do not think we ought to get too rapt in the gloss that Prime Minister Keating gives to the conclusions of Osaka. I think they are moving in the right direction—we all hope that what he says is right—but I suspect that the interpretation of others might not be quite as conclusive, in terms of those 2010 and 2020 objectives, as many of us would like.

The third thing I wanted to comment on was the fact that, in Australia, we have always had a bit of a love-hate relationship with the United States. I am one of those who feel very strongly—as I know my colleague the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons), who is in this Main Committee with me, does—that the defence relationship through ANZUS has been very important to Australia. It is also very important to other countries in our region.

What concerns me about our relationship with the United States is that the United States is still so introspective. It is an enormous economy with enormous capability, and so matters outside the United States tend to be considered to be peripheral. The Osaka meeting would have been enhanced if President Bill Clinton had been able to attend and had not been so preoccupied with his conflict with the legislature in the United States over budget processes. If President Clinton had attended, there is no doubt that the Osaka conclusions would have been so much more valuable.

That is said without prejudice to the fact that America has been a very strong supporter of the economic goals set by APEC. It is also said without prejudice to the fact that those who were there did a very good job. However, it is very important that the United States continues to be a positive advocate within APEC; that the United States President is present at meetings of the heads of government; and that the United States President, in whatever forum, remains a major participant. The President is a very important player and the United States, above all, is a critical factor in the future of APEC. It is important, therefore, that the United States continues to be encouraged to play a leading role. It is unfortunate that without the United States' presence at the highest level, the conclusions of APEC are not quite as conclusive as the rhetoric of the Prime Minister suggests.

A number of other details interest me. In the statement there is reference to the technical committee on which Neville Wran was Australia's representative. I think that the committee was called the Eminent Persons Group. The Prime Minister was lavish in his phrase. I know that he is keen on providing jobs for his colleagues, but I feel that there are many far more eminent people in the field for which APEC is noted than Neville Wran.

Indeed, it appals me that Neville Wran and people like him have been appointed as the receivers for the Australian National Line. That is not necessarily the way you solve a major national problem, and to say that Neville Wran should be the person to represent Australia in the Eminent Persons Group is absolute nonsense. If you wanted to have a politician, I believe Doug Anthony would have been far more suitable. He has been a senior trade minister and he knows most of these people personally. It is better, if you have a trade objective, that you have someone with knowledge in the field.

The relationships between the Commonwealth and the states are important. We need to recognise the very important role that state premiers and state ministers play but, for goodness sake, do not let us think that they are necessarily thinking about wider Australian interests. Nor do they have a capacity to represent Australia as well as some other people could. Indeed, we have many others of considerable distinction, not necessarily at a party political level, who could have filled that role with greater eminence and with greater capacity to turn the outcomes towards Australia's advantage than the former New South Wales Premier, Neville Wran.

The other things that I wanted to address are related to whether APEC should be a body concerned only with trade and economic issues. I know that it is an economic conference. I know we have problems with Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir's organisation—the far east sphere of cooperation or cohabitation or whatever it is called—which has had a series of meetings from which Australia has been excluded. That and the economic emphasis should not really be what this forum is about. It is important that heads of government meet, and the distinguished coterie of people who have been present at each of these three APEC meetings shows that, but there are many other issues where APEC has a capacity to make some judgment.

I am not too sure that a time when Australians were so concerned about French nuclear testing in the South Pacific was not an appropriate one for the Australian Prime Minister to have canvassed the issue. I know that the United States and some of the other countries attending might well have had a different view but Japan, the host of the meeting, certainly would have had the same view as Australia.

It is important that a country such as Australia, where there are important regional issues, uses every possible opportunity to pursue its political and economic goals. Indeed, if we do not do so, Australia will be a middle-level country which has an economy that leaves a lot to be desired and an appallingly high level of unemployment.

If APEC is to continue to have a role, we must see it not just in terms of economic conclusions but as a vehicle for heads of state to get together to address matters of significance to us all, not only in the economic field but in many others as well. I would trust that it is possible for those sorts of matters to be dealt with in the future.

The number of attendees and the realisation of the extent to which prime ministers and people such as Vice-President Gore of the United States participated make it remarkable that so much was done at the Osaka meeting. The outcome is worth while. From the opposition point of view, we look forward to at least maintaining Australia's role in the future. I was very pleased that the honourable member for Bennelong, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), identified that as his commitment. It is important that APEC is preserved, and a coalition government after the next election will do that to even greater advantage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my opening remarks I express my gratitude to the member for Aston (Mr Nugent), who has made it possible for me to participate in the debate at this stage, and to the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) for his comments. In addressing the ministerial statement on APEC the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) made the comment that farmers across Australia would be grateful for the outcome of the Osaka meeting. I think he is right: the farmers across Australia will be grateful. But it is wrong for the member for Throsby to presume on the gratitude of farmers merely as a result of several bilateral conversations and conferences on trade that have occurred recently in Osaka as an outcome of the original Bogor agreement.

PARA.TAB: Important as the outcomes are to farmers across Australia, the reality is that farmers will find themselves at the cutting edge of competition, able to participate in these new trade arrangements only if there is some sort of reform to our competition policy. Comments have been made by others—the member for New England, particularly the member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) and even those opposite—about the incapacity of Australian farmers to be competitive, largely because of the difficulties they face in finding a competitive industrial relations and waterfront structure. The cost of their goods is forced up by the non-competitive arrangements in Australia.

I do not want to be particularly critical of this paper; I welcome it. However, I was less than amused by the comments in the House of Representatives when this paper was being noted by the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), who at no stage gave any credit to the opposition for the bipartisan support that it had given the government in the area of trade liberalisation.

I am very conscious of this because, like you, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, I represent a number of horticultural industries which have felt that they have been inadequately represented and disadvantaged in the trade debate, that they have been pawns in an enormous world trade game and that the government has not recognised their needs. It has been much more difficult than the government might imagine for members of the opposition to support this trade liberalisation. Conversely, it would have been much easier for opposition members—particularly those who represent manufacturing seats, as does the member for Aston, or those such as the member for Hinkler (Mr Neville), the member for Mallee (Mr Forrest) and I, who all represent horticulture seats—to have been much more critical of the government and to have received short-term praise for standing up for the electorates—

TAB.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 1.25 p.m. to 1.38 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension, I was saying that one of the things that disappointed me about the statement on APEC made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was that he at no stage alluded to the cooperation that he had had from the opposition in achieving this trade liberalisation. Liberalisation has occurred not only through the APEC conference but as a result of the exercises of the opposition in government, of people like Prime Minister Fraser and Mr Anthony, and prior to that in the years 1971 and 1972 when the opposition when in government committed itself to joining some form of trade liberalisation.

PARA.TAB: The member for Werriwa has gone out of his way to be critical of the opposition. Even if one chose not to concede the degree of cooperation that had been inherent in the Fraser and Anthony regimes, it is certainly fair to say that under the Leader of the Opposition the opposition has in fact been totally supportive of the whole of the arrangements of trade liberalisation. It has been difficult, much more difficult than the government has sometimes conceded, in electorates such as yours, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, and mine to stand for trade liberalisation in the face of the criticism that comes from some of the industries within our electorates.

The whole APEC arrangements give great opportunities to Australian farmers, but we should never deceive ourselves by pretending that what Australia is entering into is an agreement where in fact there will be a level playing field for agricultural industries or for any other industries. When I am speaking to those people in my own electorate who are most critical of the arrangements that we have in a bipartisan way entered into for the lowering of tariff barriers, and they suggest to me that we have in some way been duped, I point out to them that, if you want an analogy about what has happened in world trade, you really ought to consider world trade as some sort of enormous card game that has in the past been played by people who had loaded decks—decks loaded decidedly to Australia's disadvantage. What has happened under both the APEC agreement and the WTO agreement is that the world trade game goes on being played by people who have loaded decks, but the decks are not as loaded as they were and all the players are obliged to play with their hands above the table instead of below the table.

That is quite an advantage, an advantage that the Prime Minister points out is expected ultimately to deliver $40 billion to Australia and by the year 2010 to create 500,000 new jobs. In common with the Leader of the Opposition and all other members of the opposition, I congratulate the Prime Minister on that having been achieved. I only wish the spirit of bipartisanship which has characterised the debate, often at the expense of opposition members, was recognised by more members of the government. The outcome of these agreements is very important, not just for Australian farmers and not just for Australian manufacturing industries, but for the entire globe.

As I have said, it is calculated that half a million new jobs could be created in Australia. What we need to appreciate is that even more important than this opportunity for job creation in Australia is the grim reality that the world population, which now sits at 5.6 billion people, by the year 2025, not long after the year 2010 which is so much a feature in the APEC agreement, will have grown to 8.5 billion people. Whereas today it is calculated that 700 million people go hungry around the globe, by the year 2025 it is calculated that, unless there is a change in our attitude to food production, 2.3 billion or a quarter of the population of the globe may well go hungry. That is one individual figure that we ought to be worried about, as a free nation in this corner of the globe, because nothing produces political instability faster than the threat of hunger, understandably so.

The tragedy we face, particularly in this corner of the globe, has been that the construction and maintenance of tariff walls has ensured that some of our major competitors are producing less food than they would otherwise produce and producing it in the face of what is increasing land degradation and pollution.

Countries like Japan and Korea have the object of being self-sufficient in food production. That self-sufficiency will never be achieved and right now that self-sufficiency is being pursued at a great deal of national expense, not only because there are trade barriers making it difficult for us to enter those countries but also because, in order to be self-sufficient in food, their farmers are being encouraged to pour on more in the way of nitrates and so add to the pollution. As we lower trade barriers, we provide greater opportunity, not only for Australian farmers to have access to the markets of Korea and Japan and other Asian markets as covered by the 18 signatories of the APEC agreement but also greater opportunity to provide those people, particularly the people of Japan and Korea, with the food they need at prices they can afford and, in addition to that, the opportunity to relieve them of the sort of environmental degradation and pollution that inevitably follows the well-intentioned but impossible objective of food self-sufficiency.
This point was very clearly made in an article in the Australian on 18 October this year written by Mr Julian Cribb who penned the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: The one way Japan and Korea can guarantee they never run short of food is to open their borders to imports and become regular customers of the most efficient producers including Australia, New Zealand, Thailand, Vietnam, Chile and the US.

PARA.TAB: If there were free trade in farm products, our security would be redoubled, as the most efficient regions would be encouraged to grow more food.
The message is simple: free trade in food eliminates risk. It yields food that is cheaper, safer, cleaner and environmentally more sustainable.

However if Japan, Korea and others pursue their myopic course, they will defeat this vital objective of stability. They will also exacerbate needless destruction of the environment, the clearing of forest on poor soils to make way for domestic food production. In densely settled areas, they will ruin their waterways with fertiliser, sediment and pesticides.

Through the absurd prices they charge their consumers, they will contribute to global inflation, higher interest rates and lower consumer purchasing power. They will also, self-defeatingly, ensure that the poor countries—often highly efficient farmers—stay poor.

SPEECH.PARA: Further up in the article, Mr Cribb stated:

With 4 billion inhabitants by the year 2030, the Asia-Pacific may well be twice as dangerous and unstable a place to live as it is today. If there is one reason for APEC, it is to curb this instability through growth, co-operation and mutual trust.

I join previous speakers in commending the government on this initiative and I join the member for Hinkler in calling for the government to embrace also those sorts of domestic reforms, particularly in the waterfront and in industrial relations, which will allow our manufacturers and farmers to retain the competitive edge and to be both the food bowl and a significant manufacturing sector for this corner of the globe.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on the APEC meeting in Osaka, one of the things that he talked about was that 60 per cent of the world's GDP was represented in APEC. That may well be a meaningful statement to those who are closely involved with the activity, putting APEC together and attending the meetings and so on, but I think it might be useful, just for the benefit of those who are much more likely to listen to what I have to say perhaps as opposed to the Prime Minister, to spell out for the record what that means in much more everyday terms. The statement about 60 per cent of the world's GDP is probably a fairly meaningless statement to most, although it is an important statement.

PARA.TAB: There are 18 countries in APEC, including ourselves, and the countries range from very small ones such as Brunei to major countries such as Canada with nearly 30 million people, China with over one billion people, Indonesia with nearly 200 million, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, the Philippines, Singapore—which is small but important—Thailand, Chinese Taipei and, of course, the United States. We are actually talking about 18 countries, where the population at the moment exceeds two billion people. That is a fair chunk of the world's population.

Mr Deputy Speaker Andrew, when you were making your valuable contribution to this place a short while ago, you mentioned the populations projected in a few years time, but the reality is that two billion people are still an awful lot of people. They are very much the people who are right on our doorstep, so to speak, with whom we are going to have a very close relationship. It is also perhaps interesting to note that, of those 18 countries, apart from Chile, which has got just under 50 per cent of its exports going to other APEC countries, there is not a single one of those countries that has less than 60 per cent of its exports going to other APEC countries.

This is a very powerful trading organisation and structure. It is not a bloc; it is not trying to lock out others. It is an attempt to liberalise world trade and to make sure that we can all gain from the process. We are talking about very substantial sums of money, very substantial blocs of people and an important international relationship within APEC itself. The other thing to mention is that a lot of these countries are rapidly growing countries with rapidly growing economies.

I was in Indonesia last year. We talk about Indonesia glibly as having 193 million people at the present time but, of course, many of those people are pretty poor. The reality is that Indonesia has a middle class, with what we would regard as a reasonable standard of living, of about 25 million people. It is not a large proportion but it is still a greater number of people than in the whole of Australia, and Indonesia is growing at a phenomenal rate of knots. Malaysia, which has a population slightly larger than ours, is growing at a rate of eight or nine per cent a year and has been for seven or eight years.

All of these countries are improving their wealth; therefore, they are improving their consumerism. Quite apart from the population growth itself, there is an improvement in living standards. That means there is more demand for products and, whether they are raw materials, whether they are finished products, whether they are skills, services or whatever it is, there is going to be increasing demand, particularly in this part of the world, for the next few years. It is important that we understand that this is a very critical and vibrant part of our future as a nation.

There have been three meetings of APEC at heads of government level—the Seattle meeting of 1993, the meeting at Bogor in Indonesia in 1994 and the just completed Osaka meeting which is the basis of this debate. The next meeting, next year, is to be in the Philippines. It is important that we remind ourselves that what it is all about is free and open trade, and investment, by all of these countries by the target dates of 2010 or 2020—2010 for the developed countries and 2020 for the developing countries.

As previous speakers have said, and the opposition acknowledges, the government has had a number of good points coming out of this round of meetings, particularly the Osaka meeting. The inclusion of food is, of course, a vital one from the point of view of Australia. But there is also a firm timetable to take the next step. It is not just some glorious talking shop; there is actually to be a firm timetable of progress. That is important.

The fact that the leaders of the major nations and of all of these nations are taking part in the discussions in itself seems to me to be fundamentally different from many of the other international structures we frequently see. So often, the bureaucrats come together, they evolve a lowest common denominator position, if you like, and that is staffed up through the various national governments—and then the leaders come together and sign something which is often not very earth-shattering at all.

This time, what we are seeing is the leaders of the countries—those who can commit their countries—coming together and sitting down to work out the principles, signing off on the agreement and then saying to the bureaucrats, `Now go and dot the i's and cross the t's.' That is a fundamental difference. In fact, it is showing the way—it seems to me—to many in the World Trade Organisation and, indeed, in G7 where we do not see that happen very often at all.

There have been a number of specific measures announced. They include, for example, the introduction of a common harmonised system of tariff classification, which is to be effective by next year; the electronic customs message system, by 1999; and a pilot scheme for mutual recognition agreements in standards, by 1997. Coming from an electorate where there are some 6,000 small businesses, many in the engineering and technical field, I can certainly say that standards and international standards are a particular sore point for many of them. They will be delighted to see that we are going to come up with some common recognised standards.

Members of this place get the opportunity to travel overseas from time to time, be it on study tours, with delegations or in other forms. I think this is a very vital element of what a member of parliament does because these days, with international trade, economy, business and communications, if you do not go and have a look, meet and talk to people overseas and see what is happening you are going to get left out of the race.

I have been fortunate in the last two or three years to go to places such as Canada, Korea, Malaysia, Singapore and Thailand as well as the United States—and all of those countries are members of APEC. I have not been to all of the APEC countries and I believe the next speaker, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), probably would claim a much more extensive travel itinerary. But he has also been in the House somewhat longer than I have, so that is reasonable.

The point I want to make is that in going to those countries you actually start to understand some of the issues and complexities that are involved in trade. You get a chance to talk to people there at government and bureaucratic levels and also to those in private business. It seems to me that that is a very important communication that we were probably not getting the advantage of 20 years ago in the way that we are today. It is that knowledge, communication and understanding that is going to help develop things like APEC in the future.

I recently attended the APEC networking conference in Adelaide which I found to be very valuable. From that contact and my subsequent visits, a number of issues came out. Firstly, we have to understand that there are cultural differences between Australia and many of the countries that we want to deal with. It is no good complaining about that. It is a reality that we have to come to grips with. We have to understand that the cultural differences in the way other countries approach doing business is going to be a factor in the way that we negotiate some of these arrangements.

Infrastructure in many of those countries is a major problem. I was in Malaysia a couple of months ago and the reality there is that they have major environmental and pollution problems. The reality there is that, although they are building modern roads right across the country, they are prone to major mud slides and rock falls and so on in many of the mountainous parts of Malaysia, and that is a major impediment.

Whilst I was there, the island of Penang—which is not only a holiday island, as most Australians would know, but also has a very heavy commercial and industrial base—lost its electricity for a full 24 hours, and then four or five days later it lost it again for a few hours. If you do not have a clean and reliable electricity supply, then as a country you have a number of problems, and often you cannot attract the businesses that you want to attract.

We have to recognise that many of these countries which do not want to go at the pace that we want to go at have problems that we do not suffer from. Many of the APEC countries also have a skills and education shortfall. For many of the countries that we are talking about, whilst there are a number of highly skilled people and highly educated people, nevertheless there are not always the education levels or the special technical knowledge that is available here. That applies to Malaysia and a number of the other APEC countries that I mentioned earlier.

It is important to look at political stability. We perhaps take that for granted here. We have a robust parliament, as the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) mentioned in the main chamber earlier this morning during a debate on another subject. I think we would all agree that it does tend to be robust on occasions, but the reality is that we actually have a very stable political system in this country. Not all the countries in APEC enjoy that benefit, and that often motivates and drives some of their actions in terms of trying to come up with trade agreements.

One of the little tricky areas—not so little but certainly very tricky—concerns human rights. We deal with and trade with and want to trade with many of these countries, and a lot of them have a different view of human rights from Australia's interpretation. We have to make some judgments about whether we close our minds to certain human rights concerns in the interests of trade or the other way around, but it is an area to be considered. Another point that I would make is that a number of these countries in APEC are receiving direct aid from Australia, so we are not only looking to trade with them, but actually pumping money into their economies.

It seems to me there are a number of opportunities in this agreement for Australian business. The large companies will already be trading overseas anyway, as they have the resources. There are a number of government agencies in these user-pays days which are trying to get in on the act and sell their services overseas, but it seems to me that the small companies are the ones that we really have to now try to encourage to take advantage of the arrangements being made under APEC.

Many of those are concerned about the costs. They do not have the knowledge of the markets, or they do not often have the time to put the effort in, but it is an area where government—of whichever persuasion after the next election—needs to put increasing emphasis on creating the environment, and particularly with micro-economic reform, to enable some of those smaller companies to take advantage of these tremendous APEC opportunities.

In my own electorate of Aston, a company called GCD International Pty Ltd recently won the national export award. A company called Decor Corporation Pty Ltd exports regularly. Another company called Kenman Kandy Pty Ltd is getting all of its market growth from export activity, because the market at home is pretty stable. We are about to announce a new export award citation for another company in my electorate that is in the macadamia nut chocolates business.

In closing, I just want to say that I welcome the Prime Minister's statement. The coalition certainly takes a bipartisan view. There are a number of challenges for us to create an environment at home that will allow Australian companies to take advantage of the opportunities in APEC, but I certainly commend the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend my colleague, who has just given a very excellent tour de raison of the realities of the Asia-Pacific region in the context of APEC. I would like to begin by commending both the former Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke, and the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for the very genuine efforts both made, with the help of a significant number of very senior officials over a range of departments of the Australian Public Service, as well as the private sector, in harnessing this country's resources to ensure our capacity to live in peace and to trade and develop a region of prosperity in what by any stretch of the imagination is the most diverse region in the world.

PARA.TAB: The APEC experiment is the product of three major heads of government meetings in Seattle, Bogor and Osaka. Next year the meeting will be at Subic Bay, in the Philippines. APEC has been based on the very simple principle that open markets generate growth. Whether we are talking about labour markets, capital markets or any other form of markets for goods and services, the important thing is that we must have the capacity in this country to serve the region, which is, in economic terms, burgeoning.

There are now 18 APEC signatories; they represent over two billion people, virtually half the world's population. As has been pointed out by previous speakers, that represents 60 per cent of the world's entire gross domestic product. In that context, the last conference in Osaka did have some very notable achievements. The most important single concrete achievement was that down payments have been made by both Japan and China—in one case, the world's premier market; in the other case, undoubtedly the world's largest growing market—toward the liberalisation of trade.

These changes were substantial. Consequently, they are but part of a total scene which we have seen developing over recent years. It has now reached the stage where we have some 700 Japanese imports and over 4,000 Chinese imports, representing a reduction of some 30 per cent in tariffs, which have been affected by the decisions taken at Osaka.

APEC is only one of a number of dynamics at work in East Asia and across the Pacific—the most notable is the development of NAFTA—but nevertheless it is in that environment that we have to see Australia's relations with the individual markets within the region, all of which are members of APEC.

The most obvious market of interest to us, apart from China and Japan, is Indonesia. It will be the fifth largest world market quite early in the next century. Consequently, the cooperation which the President of Indonesia, General Suharto, has given to the Australian government in achieving not only the outcomes of Bogor but also those of Osaka demonstrates the depth of the relationship which is being created with Indonesia, despite the constant bilateral difficulties which will probably continue to one degree or another well into the future.

Fortunately for Australia, the East Asian economies as a whole believe in the liberalisation of trade, and they believe it is good for their economies. That has been no more clearly demonstrated than by the fact that at Osaka it was possible, despite the problems of Japanese primary industry—as demonstrated also by some concerns shown by China, Malaysia and others—that all those countries were prepared to work together to achieve the overall objective that by the year 2010 all developed countries will have reduced their trade barriers, and by 2020 the developing world will follow.

Various commentators have been cynical about the conference, asking: what does it really mean? Is there a definition of free trade which is acceptable to all the members of APEC? The reality suggests that there probably is not. Nevertheless these steps have been taken and they are significant.
But we should be wise to the reality of diplomacy and of international trade. The Malaysian Minister for International Trade and Industry, Mrs Rafidah Aziz, said:

SPEECH.PARA: A voluntary commitment means a non-binding commitment.
She went on to say:
There is no obligation on any APEC member to liberalise whether it be by the year 2010 or the year 2020.
Japan's Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Yohei Kono, also stressed the importance of the `voluntary' nature of the liberalisation commitment which was made, initially, at Bogor.

PARA.TAB: We have to be very careful not to allow our imaginations to run ahead of the reality, which will change from time to time. Nevertheless, an objective has been set and accepted by all 18 signatory members. It is, naturally, the responsibility of Australia to make sure that it is fully carried through.

The difficulty of maintaining the United States of America's interest in the Asia-Pacific region is something of profound importance to Australia's foreign policy, as well as to our trade policy. In fact, one of the most important things that APEC can do is ensure that American attention is focused on what is really happening in East Asia.

China's down payment, to which I referred, should bring it closer to membership of the World Trade Organisation, from which it has been excluded. Nevertheless, there is a major problem in the relationship between China and the United States. That problem could, in a sense, become institutionalised, resulting in a stand-off if China's membership of the WTO were indefinitely delayed.

APEC is already spearheading moves for the new World Trade Organisation's global round of trade liberalisation. The Prime Minister is right in saying that the APEC negotiation process is the biggest game in town when it comes to the reduction of international trading difficulties. Nevertheless, the status of Australia within the region and in our bilateral relationships with those APEC members leaves us very little room for complacency, either about the future of the organisation or about our bilateral links.

I refer specifically to the question of a secure framework within which Australia can look to its regional economic future. Each one of those members will ultimately be making decisions which are of political and economic benefit to itself. The genius of APEC will depend on how the commonality of interest can be harnessed for the betterment of the entire region. That is why there is broad support for the 2010 and 2020 plans for regional trade liberalisation. But we must not lose sight of the fact that, ultimately, there is no way to compel APEC members to meet those targets.

There are internal conflicts within the structure of APEC which could threaten its cohesion in the future. There are conflicts over trade between the United States and Japan, conflicts between the United States and China—to which I have referred—and conflicts between South Korea, Japan and China.

We have Malaysia's continuing campaign to deny Australia a place in Asia, and their emphasis on the establishment of their rival organisation—or sub-rival organisation—called the EAEC. Perhaps the retirement of Prime Minister Mahathir will see a new dawn in Australia's relations with Malaysia. Nevertheless, in the context of ASEAN, Australia is not seen as one of them. That is going to continue to be a problem in the future.

Recently, the celebrated diplomat and statesman Henry Kissinger said he had observed that market economic systems were efficient for increasing gross national product, but wondered whether they closed the gap between rich and poor sufficiently to ensure political stability in societies. We must never lose sight of the fact that, for many Asian nations, political and social stability are still important considerations. They transcend their economic development. In other words, they are willing to trade off some economic efficiency, provided it gives them political stability which then reduces the vulnerability of governments.

In most booming Asian economies—apart from Singapore and Hong Kong—governments still exercise wide economic influence which they are reluctant to relinquish. That is why it is important in the context of APEC that we maintain the structure of heads of government meetings. It is not a case of advice permeating up but a case of policy initiatives permeating down.

Australia should also beware of assuming that APEC is the only economic game in the region, or for that matter in the world. We could well be deluding ourselves that the East Asian economic caucus promoted by Mohamad Mahathir is an unimportant subgroup. That was emphasised clearly by the fact that he has been able to promote the EAEC as the true Asian economic voice and to exclude Australia, the United States and New Zealand. While he has tried to get Japan into their membership, that is not absolutely clear. The important thing is that we have been denied a place at the first Asian-European union summit next March in Bangkok, which should demonstrate that the significance of Australia in the region is not always seen from the north in the same light as it is seen from the south. We should be very conscious of that fact.

The EAEC's viability as a separate entity from APEC should safeguard its relations with Europe. That is part of the Mahathir plan. But the Europeans now see the development of Asia as of profound importance for the next stage of their development in the context of the European Community. Again Australia has to be in a position where we can deal with both the European group and the Asian group.

In my concluding remarks I want to draw attention to the fact that I believe the time has now come for the next major set of reforms in the APEC context. Till now, APEC has been essentially an economic entity and very little attention has been given to the fact that, at the ministerial level, there are also many meetings taking place on a host of other quasi-economic issues involving social development, education and financial matters; a host of cooperative ventures have been developed.

The weakness we have in the APEC context is that there is not yet in place a mechanism by which there is a capacity for the populations of the region to feel associated with the product of APEC. In that context I put forward the proposition, which I hope will be furthered at Subic Bay, that, just as the Europeans had a Council of Europe and now have a European Parliament, the first steps should be taken toward ensuring that in the Asia-Pacific region there is a similar representative body for the parliaments of the region, able to make a contribution to the APEC process.

In 1991, in this parliament, I suggested that the time had come for Australia to take a role in the establishment of a parliamentary Asia-Pacific forum. I prepared the first discussion paper which was considered at the Singapore meeting. With the close cooperation of the Japanese, in particular the former Prime Minister, Mr Nakasone, Australia and Japan have been the two pillars upon which the Asia-Pacific Parliamentary Forum have been built. But there are still difficulties in getting the APPF structure—which has 25 members, some of whom are not members of APEC—into the position where it can have a logical working framework within the APEC process and give it a much wider base. The 1992 Tokyo declaration establishing the APPF described its objectives as identifying and discussing matters of common concern and interest and highlighting them in a global context; deepening the understanding of the parliaments of the region, of policy concerns, of interests and experiences of individual countries and what they have learnt; examining the critical political, social, cultural, economic and defence relationships and linkages resulting from economic growth and integration; encouraging and promoting regional cooperation at all levels in matters of common concern to the region; and playing the role of national parliamentarians in furthering, in their respective countries, a sense of regional cohesion, understanding and cooperation.

Since the Tokyo meeting there have been meetings in the Philippines and in Mexico, and the next meeting is set down for January 1996, in Thailand. The forum is effective. It should be the future voice of the people of the region, working closely with APEC to ensure a safe and secure world for us all. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mrs Crosio) adjourned.
